loans.name: Joséphine

texts.fr: Née en 1960, B. Joséphine vit depuis 50 ans au quartier Midombo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Joséphine a deux enfants, dont un est scolarisé. Joséphine ne vit plus avec son mari. Joséphine vit donc seule et assure seule ses différents besoins. N’ayant jamais été à l’école, Joséphine vend du charbon de bois à son domicile, depuis une dizaine d’année. Parallèlement à cette activité, Joséphine vend également du maïs à son domicile. Joséphine s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. L’activité de Joséphine lui procure des revenus l’aidant à faire face à ses besoins. Joséphine est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu cinq crédits qu’elle a tous bien remboursés. Actuellement, Joséphine n’a pas pu réunir les moyens financiers suffisants pouvant l’aider à augmenter davantage le stock de ses produits et à mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle. C’est ce qui l’amène à solliciter auprès de ALIDé, un sixième prêt.
texts.en:
Born in 1960, Joséphine B. has been living for 50 years in the neighborhood of Midombo in Cotonou, economic capital of Benin. She has two children, one of whom attends school. She no longer lives with her husband and provides alone for her various needs. Never having attended school, Joséphine sells wood charcoal from her home. Parallel to this activity, she also sells corn from her home. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, international market of Benin. Joséphine’s activity provides her with an income, which helps her meet her needs. She is an old time ALIDé customer having received five loans that she reimbursed fully. Currently, Joséphine is not able to bring together sufficient financial means to help her increase the stock of her products and to better meet the demand of her customers. This is what is driving her to request a sixth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bags of wood charcoal and corn.

loans.name: Cleofel

texts.en:
Cleofel S. is from the village of Malipayon, Pangantucan Bukidnon. She is 35 years old and married with five school-aged children. To make a living, she has a business providing rice milling services to local community members. She has been in this business for over five years and earns approximately 12,000 to 20,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Cleofel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI and is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used for maintenance of the rice mill. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Cleofel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: maintenance of the rice mill.

loans.name: Kabembe Women's Group, Mukono

texts.en:
B. Rehema, shown in the small photo at the top, also appears in the big photo as the group leader. Standing 4th from the left is Namukwaya Prossy who did not receive a loan from her lending group of Kabembe although she appeared in the group photo.

Rehema is 46 years old and married with seven children with only one child still in school. She also takes care of her other siblings. She has a salon and also a hall in which she shows movies to her customers. She has been in business for twelve years and her major strong point is the quality of what she does.

Although Rehema is able to make 350,000/= as weekly profits, she is still faced with a challenge of the lack of enough capital. She needs a loan to be able to restock her salon with more hair chemicals and hair pieces as well as having more CDs and DVDs for for better and more up-to-date viewing.

loans.use: To restock her salon and to buy more CDs and DVDs

loans.name: Meirambek

texts.en:
Meirambek is 39 years old and lives with his wife in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a house.
Meirambek operates a spare parts trading business with his wife. He has run this business since 2000, and has gained a great deal of experience. Initially, he operated a mobile spare parts trading business, but over the years he has expanded the business and in 2008 opened his own spare parts trading store. Meriambek purchases the spare parts and his wife sells them at their store.
Besides this business, Meirambek operates a taxi service in his spare time. With a lot of hard work and determination, their working capital now exceeds 6,000,000 MNT (~ 4225 USD), and the profit margins for the business are 30 per cent. In addition, Meirambek's wife has a savings account with 900,000 MNT (~ 635 USD) with the bank.
Meirambek has a great business mind and is focused on the future. He says, “I would like to enlarge my house for my family.” He is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan to purchase spare parts from Russia for his business.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts

loans.name: Doctor Toryale Group

texts.en:
Samena is the leader of the Doctor Toryale group. She is married with four children, and lives in the 11th district of Kabul, Afghanistan.
Samena wants to take a loan for her business of quilt making. She has been involved in this business for more than 15 years and is quite experienced. She wants to expand and progress her business and support her children in acquiring a good education. With her loan, she wants to buy essential things for her business.
Samena wants to express her happiness about this effective process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy necessary materials for her business

loans.name: Celia's Group

texts.en:
Celia S. is from the village of Baculud, Amulung, Cagayan. She is 48 years old and the leader of a 4-member group loan offered by ASKI.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, each is collectively responsible for paying back the entire loan if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Celia is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Celia owns and operates a service-based business, primarily from providing photography services to local community members.  Celia has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

Celia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Celia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase materials needed to expand her services. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Celia from ASKI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 
---------------------------------
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Purchase materials needed to expand her business.

loans.name: Shafqat's Group

texts.en: Shafqat is a very supportive lady. She always ready to help people. She operates a baby dolls selling business. She purchases the dolls from various markets and sells it to the community. Her business requires her fully attention and she wonderfully manages her family and business. She also helps her husband in his vegetable selling business by arranging the vegetables on a cart. She does this on daily basis. She is applying for a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to expand her husband’s vegetable selling business.

loans.use: To buy seasonal vegetables for vegetable selling business

loans.name: Lary's Group

texts.en:
Lary B. is from the village of Magsaysay, Baliangao. She is the leader of a four-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Lary is 42 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Lary has a retail business selling dry goods (rice). The main source of income for the business comes from selling her own harvested rice. Lary has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2004, Lary joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Lary is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used as additional capital for rice production. This loan will be her seventeenth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: As additional capital for rice production

loans.name: Lucie Jacqueline

texts.fr: H. Lucie Jacqueline est née le 08 Janvier 1974 et vit depuis cinq ans au quartier Ayélawadjè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Lucie Jacqueline est une célibataire, ayant à sa charge deux enfants. Lucie Jacqueline vit seule avec les deux enfants à charge et supporte leurs charges. Lucie Jacqueline a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Depuis une dizaine d’année, Lucie Jacqueline mène comme activité, la vente des gâteaux de blé, mais aussi des chips de bananes à la devanture d’un collège de Cotonou. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Lucie Jacqueline s’approvisionne. Lucie Jacqueline a obtenu une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de la clientèle, Lucie Jacqueline ambitionne augmenter son fonds de roulement et produire plus de galettes et de chips de bananes, afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. C’est pourquoi Lucie Jacqueline sollicite un deuxième crédit.
texts.en:
Lucie Jacqueline H. was born 8 January 1974 and has lived for the past five years in the Ayélawadjè borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Lucie Jacqueline is unmarried, with two children under her care. She lives with the two children and is their sole support. She interrupted school at the secondary level. For the past ten years Lucie Jacqueline has sold wheat flatcakes and banana chips at a stall facing a Cotonou secondary school (college). She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. Lucie Jacqueline was already granted one loan from ALIDé, which was repaid in full. Faced with an increasing customer demand, she wants to boost her working capital and produce more flatcakes and banana chips, to increase customer satisfaction. This is why she is requesting a second loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wheat flour, sugar and vegetable oil, to prepare flatcakes.

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Chona Banjo is a 51-year old married woman who lives in Brgy Butong, Manjuyod, Negros Oriental.  She earns her living by running her general store and by buying and selling livestock, banana, corn and dried fish.

Chona and her husband have 4 children who are adult age. Two of them have their own families while one attends school.  Their other girl helps her mother run the general store business.

Chona joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004.  With the help of her loans to run her business, from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase her family's income.  Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 6,000.

Chona is a loan member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 29,500 was used to fund operations of her general store, and had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions.  Now she is borrowing for her 14th cycle loan, the amount of Php 29,000, she intends to buy and sell of livestock, banana, corn and dried fish business.  Chona is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.
--------------------------------
About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: Kolo Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
S. Lawrence, appearing in the small photo at the top left, also appears in the big photo as their group leader.

Lawrence is a hardworking and friendly man with a business selling dried fish and fresh produce from Nantabulilirwa trading centre of Mukono. He has been in business for three years and buys his fish from the landing sites in Mukono as well as buying the produce like potatoes and cassava from the farmers around his village.

Lawrence is grateful that he is able to access loans from Pearl Microfinance and this enables him to take good care of his wife and children. He needs a loan to be able to restock his businesses.

loans.use: To buy more dried fish and more potatoes and cassava

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: A. Marie est née le 02 Janvier 1972 et est mariée à SEFOU Wassi. Marie est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais Marie a un autre enfant à sa charge.  Il y a environs trois ans que la famille s’est installée au quartier Yagbé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Marie a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire. Mais depuis trois ans, Marie mène comme activité, la vente de produits de SOBEBRA (boissons alcoolisées, sucreries). A côté de cette activité, Marie prépare et vend de la nourriture à PK 3 à Cotonou. Marie s’approvisionne en boissons à la SOBEBRA. Marie  a obtenu une fois déjà un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Marie sollicite un deuxième prêt afin d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’élever le niveau de son activité ; ce qui lui permettra d’accroître sa clientèle et de se faire plus de revenu.
texts.en:
Marie A. was born 2 January 1972 and is married to Wassi SEFOU. She is the mother of two children, all having attended (or still attending) school. Marie herself has attended school to secondary level. She also has another child under her care. Three years ago the family settled in the Yagbé borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. The couple shares family expenses. For the past three years Marie has been selling SODEBRA products (alcoholic beverages, soft drinks). As a parallel activity, she prepares and sells food at PK3 in Cotonou. She gets her bottled supplies at SODEBRA. Marie has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was repaid in full. She is now requesting a second loan to increase her working capital and raise the level of her activity. This will allow her to expand her customer base and generate more revenue.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy non-alcoholic beverages and mineral water

loans.name: Evelyn's Group

texts.en:
Evelyn L. is from the town of Benito Soliven. She is 50 years old. Evelyn is the leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Evelyn is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a business that raises livestock, primarily pigs for breeding. Evelyn has been in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Evelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Evelyn from ASKI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 
---------------------------------------
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase livestock feed and other supplies.

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en:
Rose R. is from the village of San Jose, Enrile, Cagayan. She is 45 years old. Rose is the leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Rose is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Rose owns and operates a butcher shop, selling poultry meat in the market.  Rose has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 11,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rose joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rose has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI.  Rose is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell.  This loan will be the second loan taken out by Rose from ASKI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 
------------------------------------------
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Adèle

texts.fr: Née en 1975, H. Adèle est mariée à YEBA Augustin et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Adèle vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari au quartier Kpondéhou à Cotonou, depuis quatre ans environs. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Adèle a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire, et a appris ensuite la couture. Adèle exerce cette activité, et parallèlement, elle vend des tissus et confectionne également des tenues qu’elle vend à Scoa-gbéto à Cotonou. Adèle a dix ans d'expérience dans cette activité. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Adèle s’approvisionne. Adèle est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui a obtenu antérieurement quatre crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Très sollicitée par sa clientèle, Adèle sollicite auprès de ALIDé un cinquième prêt en vue de renforcer son activité de vente de tissus et d’accroître son chiffre d’affaire.
texts.en:
Born in 1975, Adèle H. is married to Augustin YEBA and is the mother of two children, both attending school. For about four years she has lived with her children and husband in the Kpondéhou borough of Cotonou. The couple shares family expenses. Adele interrupted school at the secondary level, and afterwards learned sewing. Adele works as a seamstress, and also sells pieces of fabric and tailors clothing she sells at Scoa-Gbéto in Cotonou. She has acquired ten years of working experience. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. Adele is a regular client of ALIDé, and was granted four previous loans, all of which have been repaid in full. Much in demand by her customers, she is now requesting a fifth loan to strengthen her fabric-selling activity and increase her turnover.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pieces of fabric

loans.name: Rizel

texts.en:
Rizel V. is a 38 year old married woman who supports her family by operating a fish vending business. She lives in Brgy Malo, Siaton, Negros Oriental with her husband and 3 children, who are adults.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of NWTF and her own efforts.  By working hard in her fish vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average monthly income of Php 30,000.

Rizel is now borrowing Php 19,500 to support her fish vending business.  This will be her 7th cycle loan from NWTF.  Her previous loan of Php 27,000, which she paid off within its term, was another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Rizel aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well being.  
----------------------------------------------
About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: C6207 Abishyizehamwe Group

texts.en:
Laetitie is 32 years old and is a proven entrepreneur known in the business of selling meat. She joined a group called Abishyizehamwe of which she is the president. The group owns a butcher shop where they sell cow meat and which they open from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day. This is their second successful year.

Laetitie and her team are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company which hopefully will allow them to satisfy the demand of their customers. It will enable them to sell the meat of more than one cow per day and also start selling sheep and goat meat in order to cover their customer needs.

With this loan, the group hopes to earn more profits which in turn will allow each member of the group to start saving as well as taking care of his/her family. In addition, they will also be able to reserve funds for future reinvestment in their business.

loans.use: To purchase  one sheep, goat and more than one cow to increase the quantity of meat for sale

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Heng C., 65, resides in Dong Kor, near Phnom Penh city.  She is a widow and mother of one son, a truck driver who is married.  

With the palm-climbing season approaching, C. wants to take this opportunity to earn extra income by investing in the sugar trade.  Because C. doesn’t have capital, she decided to seek assistantance from HKL.  She will use her loan to buy palm sugar from palm climbers and retail the sugar at the market.

loans.use: Buying palm sugar and retail it at the market.

loans.name: Lilia's Group

texts.en:
Lilia M. is from the village of Maluno Norte. She is 48 years old. Lilia is the leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Lilia is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lilia owns & operates a business that prepares and sells snacks such as soup, noodles and native cakes. Lilia has been in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Lilia joined ASKI to access financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell.  This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lilia from ASKI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 
-----------------------------------
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell.

loans.name: Flora's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Flora M. is from the village of Salimpuno, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old and is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if they are delinquent or default. Flora is married and is blessed with three adult children. She owns and operates a cassava plantation. She has been engaged in her business for more than fifteen years earning 3,000 PHP monthly net income. In 2005, Flora joined PMPC to access its programs and services. She is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her cassava plantation. This loan will be her 9th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her cassava plantation

loans.name: Sèdé Yvette

texts.fr: Née en 1955, G. Sèdé Yvette vit depuis près de 55 ans au quartier Missessin  à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Sèdé Yvette est mariée à KAKPO Martin et est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Sèdé Yvette vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les charges de la famille. Sèdé Yvette a très peu fréquenté. Il y a près de deux ans, afin d’apporter une aide financière à sa famille, Sèdé Yvette vend divers produits (dentifrices, lait, conserves, pâtes alimentaires, savons, biscuits, couscous, bougies, etc.) à la devanture de sa maison. De façon secondaire, Sèdé Yvette vend du charbon de bois, ce qui lui permet d’avoir une autre source de revenu. Sèdé Yvette achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu trois crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Sèdé Yvette sollicite un quatrième prêt afin d’augmenter le volume de son activité et de mieux répondre à la forte demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1955, Sèdé Yvette G. has been living for the past 55 years in the Missessin borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Martin KAKPO and is the mother of one child who has had schooling. She herself has not attended school very much. Sèdé Yvette helps her husband deal with family expenses. To bring financial support to her family over the past two years, Sèdé Yvette has been selling various products from the front of her home (toothpaste, milk, canned goods, pasta, soap, cookies, couscous, candles, etc.). As a secondary activity she sells charcoal, which provides her with an additional source of income. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. She is a regular client of ALIDé, having already been granted three previous loans, all reimbursed in full. She is now requesting a fourth loan to increase her activity and respond to a strong customer demand.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products (sugar, pasta, couscous, milk, cookies, soap, canned goods)

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en: Carolina T. is from the village of Poblacion, Damulog, Bukidnon. She is 62 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Carolina owns and operates a specialized retail business, selling seafood products including dried fish, chorizo (pork sausage), and other items in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twelve years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Carolina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Carolina plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family’s income. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine K. is a 55 year old married woman who supports her family by engaging in a food vending business. She lives in Boyco, Bayawan, Negros Oriental with her husband and their 2 children who are adults.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her food vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 15,000.

Now Josephine is borrowing Php 25,000 for additional working capital for her food vending business. This will be her 15th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 25,000, which she paid off within its term, was another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Josephine aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well being.
-------------------------------------
About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Addtional working capital.

loans.name: C2904 Abisunganye Group

texts.en:
Josiane is 35 years old and is married with two children who are 2 and 4 years old. She is the president of a group called Abisunganye which is commonly known in the business of selling clothes, mainly children’s clothes. The group has been in this business for about five years and the hours of their business are from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day except Saturday.

Josiane and her team are now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding their business through adding a variety of styles such as jeans and women’s clothes. They also plan to start selling children’s shoes as they seem to be highly in demand by a number of their customers in this area.

With this business expansion, this team will hopefully earn more profits which, in turn, will allow each member of the group to build a secure future for his/her children and maintain the sustainability of their business.

loans.use: To add a variety of styles such as jeans, women's clothes, etc.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
"Lucia E. is a 48 year-old woman living in the town of Yardahan, Basay, Negro Oriental.  She is married and has 7 school-aged children.  To make a living, Lucia owns and operates a a sari sari (general) store in the local community.  Lucia has been engaged in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 10000 Php a month.

In 2007, Lucia joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Lucia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 Php from NWTF. Lucia is now requesting a new loan of 17000 Php to purchase additional products to sell.  The loan will be the 9th cycle loan taken out by the borrower from NWTF.  Lucia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to pay the tuition fees of her children.
---------------------------------
About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon."

loans.use: Purchase additional product to sell.

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en:
Vestine is 30 years old and is married with two children who are 1 and 3 years old. She is commonly known in the business of wholesaling cosmetics products including body lotion, Colgate (toothpaste), etc. Vestine has been in this business for about three years.

Vestine is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business by adding more products that she can wholesale in her business. Those additional products will include a variety of jewelry, hygienic papers, etc. In addition, Vestine plans to start wholesaling a large quantity of sugar, as it seems to be highly in demand in her village.

Through the access of this loan, Vestine has a hope for the future.

loans.use: To add more products that she can wholesale in her business

loans.name: Emely

texts.en: Emely V. is from the village of Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 29 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Emely owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Emely joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Emely is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Houssie

texts.fr: Née en 1963 à Adjohoun dans le département de l’Ouémé, A. Houssie vit depuis 25 ans au quartier Agbodjèdo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Houssie est mariée à AHOLOUKPE Innocent et est mère de trois enfants, dont deux sont à sa charge. Houssie vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari ; et vient en aide à son mari en ce qui concerne les différentes charges familiales. Houssie n’a pas été à l’école. Pour assurer ses besoins, Houssie prépare et vend de la nourriture (riz, pâte de maïs, pâte de tubercule d'igname, accompagnés de divers sauce de tomate) à son domicile, depuis 14 ans environs. Houssie se ravitaille à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Houssie a reçu auparavant deux prêts de ALIDé et les a tous bien remboursés. Houssie sollicite un troisième prêt pour rehausser son activité et augmenter son chiffre d’affaire, et par ricochet, son revenu.
texts.en:
Born in 1963 in Adjohoun in the Ouémé Department, Houssie A. has been living for the past 25 years in the Agbodjèdo borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Houssie is married to Innocent AHOLOUKPE and is the mother of three children, of which two are under her care. She lives with her children and husband, whom she assists regarding the various family expenses. She has not attended school. To meet her needs over the past 14 years, Houssie has prepared and sold food preparations from her home (rice, cornmeal mush, yam tuber mush, accompanied by various tomato-based sauces). She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. Houssie has already been granted two loans from ALIDé, both of which have been repaid in full. She is now requesting a third loan to increase her activity and consequently her income.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bags of rice, yam tubers and sauce condiments

loans.name: Brigida

texts.en:
"Brigida S. is a 58 year-old woman living in the town of Brgy II Siaton, Negros Oriental.  She is married and has 7 adult children.  To making a living, Brigida owns and operates a business harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community.  Brigida has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3000 Php a month.

Brigida joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Brigida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 19500 Php from NWTF. Brigida is now requesting a new loan of 19500 Php to purchase additional products to sell.  The loan will be her 7th from NWTF.  Brigida plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.
------------------------------------
About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon."

loans.use: Purchase additoonal products to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Hab

texts.en:
Hab M., age 50, is married and resides with her children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has six children and stays at home as a housewife to look after the children and do household chores.

Her husband (pictured) raises ducks and chickens for sale, earning an income of 1.25 USD per day. Their standard of living has been improved since her husband has had this business. The family is also assisted by three of her children who are currently employed at different workplaces.

Hab M. is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to purchase a plot of farmland to expand their agricultural output for a better income for the family. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Francois

texts.en:
Francois is 26 years old and is still single. He has two years of experience in the business of selling goods in his shop. His shop includes a variety of goods as his photo indicates. His shop is open from early in the morning until late in the evening hours.

Francois is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that he can expand his business by purchasing a variety of products which seem to be highly in demand in his village. Those goods will include foodstuffs - mainly rice, sugar, beans, Irish potatoes, sweet potatoes, etc.

With these additional goods, Francois hopes to earn more profits which, in turn, will allow him to start saving for further reinvestment in his business.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs for his store

loans.name: Marivic's Group

texts.en:
Marivic P. is from the village of Cablong, Sta.Barbara, Pangasinan. She is 34 years old. Marivic is the leader of a 3-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Marivic is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marivic owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income from the business comes from selling vegetables in the local community. Marivic has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month

In 2009, Marivic joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business activities.  Marivic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  Marivic is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and for working capital.  This loan will be the third loan taken out by Marivic from ASKI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 
-----------------------------------------------
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase additional inventory, working capital.

loans.name: Siony's Group

texts.en:
Siony B., 40, is from the village of Santiago. She is the leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Siony is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Siony raises livestock, mainly pigs for fattening and sale.  Siony has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month

In 2007, Siony joined ASKI to access financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business activities.  Siony has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. Siony is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and supplies. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Siony from ASKI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 
--------------------------------
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Purchase livestock feed and supplies.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mao K. (pictured with her daughter) is age 58, is widowed, and resides with her children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has five children.

K. is engaged in a business selling Cambodian traditional cakes, earning a gross income of 2.50 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. The business is also assisted by her daughter who always helps her mother in producing cakes, thus earning an income of 1.50 USD per day. Four of K.’s children are currently employed at different workplaces to earn their own living and to support the family as well.

The family’s standard of living has been improved since K. and her daughter have had this business. K. is requesting a loan of 800 USD to purchase a motorbike for one her children to use to commute to work at the factory. This is K.’s first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for one of her children to use for commuting

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San B., age 46, is married and resides with her children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has five children.

B. is engaged in a business purchasing rice from the local farmers and reselling it in the market, earning a gross income of USD 2.50 per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband is employed at a local government religion department, earning an income of USD 3 per day.

Their standard of living has been improved since B. and her husband have had these businesses. B. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase a truck to transport rice to sell. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy a truck to transport rice for sale

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia H. is a 50 year old, married woman who supports her family as a food vendor.  She also runs a tricycle business.  She lives in Brgy Salong, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental with her husband Ramil, 40 years old, a tricycle driver.  They have 4 children between the ages of 13-24.  Three of them currently go to school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1999 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts.  By working hard in her food vending and tricycle business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 6,000.

Ofelia is now borrowing Php 16,000 so she can repair and maintenance her cycle and to support her food vending business.  This will be her 19th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon.  Her previous loan of Php 16,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Ofelia aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way. 
-------------------------------
About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Reapir and maintenance of tricycle and additional capital for food vending.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline O. is a 29 year old mother of four children who lives in Nyalenda Kisumu Kenya.  She is a business woman who has been selling fish since 2008, after she quit vending vegetables. 

With her business she supports her family.  Her husband doesn’t have a stable job.

She wants to increase her stock and expand her business so she can earn enough income to enable her to build and own rental houses and to educate her children.  She wishes to get a loan of Ksh. 20000.  That she says will help put her on a course to achieve her goals.

loans.use: Increase stock of supplies.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Soy

texts.en: Soy S., age 37, is married and resides with her children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has five children. She is employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of USD 2 per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband (pictured) has his motorbike with a trailer attached to provide transportation services to the workers at the garment factory, earning an income of USD 3 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since S. and her husband have had these businesses. S. is requesting a loan of 600 USD to purchase a new motorbike with a new trailer for her husband. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike with a new trailer

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Sam N., age 48, is married and resides with her children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has four children. She is engaged in a business selling of various kinds of soft drinks in her village, earning a gross income of USD 11 per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband is a mechanic, earning a gross income of USD 13 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since N. and her husband have had these businesses. N. is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to purchase more mechanic supplies for her husband. (N.'s husband is pictured with his son.)

loans.use: To buy more mechanic supplies for her husband's business

loans.name: Oscar's Group

texts.en:
Oscar M. is from the village of Bolinao.  He is 60 years old and the leader of a 8-member group loan offered by ASKI.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Oscar M.'s Group.

Oscar is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Oscar owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community.  Oscar has been in business for over 12 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2008, Oscar joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Oscar has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI to purchase additional products to sell.  Oscar is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP to purchase new items to expand his product offering. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Oscar from ASKI.  He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business. 
-----------------------------
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Purchase new items to expand product offering.

loans.name: Hak

texts.en:
Hah V., 45, (husband pictured) sews clothes in the garment industry.  She can earn a salary of $100 or $120 and this helps to met her family’s daily expenses. She also relies on the income from her husband who drives a motorcycle taxi around the capital of Phnom Penh. 

They have three teenage children.  One of them is jobless and other two are employed.  Hak hopes to encourage her unemployed child to get a job, but she has no cash to start a business.  So, Hak is applying for a loan that will allow her to buy clothes and beauty salon accessories for her child to sell.

loans.use: Buy clothes and beauty salon accessories for her child to sell.

loans.name: Benta

texts.en:
Benta A. sells charcoal in Nyalenda Kisumu, Kenya.  It's a business that she has been doing for the past six years.  Before that she sold groundnuts, but that didn't generate enough income. 

Ever since she started selling charcoal, business has been better in terms of customers and income.  Benta wants to expand her business by increasing her stock, so that she can achieve a dream of having her own house.  She wishes to get a loan of Ksh. 20,000.

loans.use: Increase her stock.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr: N. Jeanne est née le 01 Août 1972 et s’est installée au quartier Kpondéhou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, il y a environs 15 ans. Mariée à KOUNOU Paul Pierre, Jeanne est mère de trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Le couple a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de leurs enfants. Jeanne subvient, au même titre que son mari aux besoins de la famille. Après son abandon des classes, Jeanne a commencé depuis huit ans, la vente de bouillie (faite à base de maïs) à la devanture de sa maison. Jeanne s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Jeanne est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu antérieurement quatre crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Dans le but d'augmenter sa production journalière et de satisfaire plus sa clientèle, Jeanne sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un autre prêt.
texts.en:
Jeanne N. was born on 1st August 1972 and settled down in the Kpondéhou district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin, around 15 years ago. Married to Paul Pierre KOUNOU, Jeanne is mother to three children, all of whom are at school. The couple have another child in their care, as well as their own children. Together with her husband, Jeanne provides for the family's needs. After she left school she began around eight years ago to sell "bouillie", a type of porridge (made from corn), in front of her house. Jeanne gets her stocks in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. She is an old customer of ALIDé, having had four previous loans, all of which she paid back without incident. In order to increase her daily production and to satisfy her customers more readily, Jeannie is applying for another loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bags of corn and sugar for the preparation of "bouillie"

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase hair extensions

loans.name: Tuy

texts.en: Tuy S., age 39, is married and resides with her children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She has two children. She is engaged in the business of selling vegetables at a local market in the province, earning an income of USD 4.60 per day to help cover the family expenses. She also raises cows at home to do farming on her own plot of farmland. Her husband operates his motorbike as a driver, earning an income of USD 2.60 per day. Their standard of living has improved since S. and her husband have had these businesses. S. is requesting a loan of 1,200 USD to purchase fruits to sell. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fruits to sell

loans.name: Adelaida's Group

texts.en:
Adelaida M. is from the village of Sandiat West. She is 56 years old and the leader of an eight member group loan offered by ASKI.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Adelaida M.'s Group.

Adelaida is married and has 8 adult-aged children. To make a living, Adelaida owns and operates a tailoring business in the local community. Adelaida has been engaged in her business for over 35 years and earns approximately 18,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Adelaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business activities.  Adelaida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 28,000 PHP from ASKI to purchase additional fabrics and materials. 

Adelaida is requesting a new loan of 35000 PHP to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and threads.  This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Adelaida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her services. 
------------------------------
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Purchase additional tailoring equipment.

loans.name: Gemma's Group

texts.en:
Gemma B. is from the village of Tabon. She is 42 years old. Gemma is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. 

Gemma is married. To make a living, Gemma owns & operates a "Food Vending" business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from the income of her husband in farming. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2008, Gemma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Gemma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase products for cooking

loans.name: C6205 Twitezimbere Group

texts.en:
Rea is 50 years old and is married with three children who are 6, 10 and 24 years old. She is the president of a group called Twitezimbere. This group is commonly known in the business of selling foodstuffs such as bananas, beans, potatoes, etc. The group has been in this business for two years and the hours of the business are from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day except Saturday.

Rea and her team are requesting a Kiva loan which will be used to expand their business through purchasing a large quantity of foodstuffs so that they can even start wholesaling. Once they start wholesaling, they hope that their revenue will increase to the extent that they will be able to share the dividends and create a reserve for the financial stability of their business.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of foodstuffs

loans.name: Pamela Awino

texts.en:
Pamela Awino A., 38, is a married woman who has four children.  She opened a boutique after getting tired and bored of being a housewife, in 2009.  At that time, her husband was the sole breadwinner.

Since she started her boutique, Pamela Awino has managed to raise money to help support her family's expenses.

She wants to expand her business and wishes to get a loan worth Ksh. 20000 to increase her stock.

loans.use: Increase her stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase a car to provide taxi services

loans.name: Anifat

texts.en: Anifat sells mouth-watering Nigerian cooked foods. She loves this business because of the opportunity to serve her customers. She hopes to expand and grow her business into a classic restaurant. She is 40 years old, married with 3 children. Her children attend school. Her husband is a mechanic and he also supports their home. She is requesting the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok S., age 47, is married and resides with her children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She has three children. She is engaged in the business of selling cakes and duck eggs at the rubber plantation, earning an income of USD 2.40 per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband operates his motorbike as a driver from his village to the market, earning an income of USD 3.30 per day. Their standard of living has improved since S. and her husband have had these businesses. S. is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to purchase a machine to produce animal food. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a machine to produce animal food

loans.name: Perjolen

texts.en:
Perjolen S. is a 47-year-old married woman who lives in Sto. Hunob, Brgy Salong, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by engaging in a vegetable vending business. Perjolen’s 49-year-old husband, Joseph, is a farmer. They have 5 children between 10 – 21 years old who are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Perjolen joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in vegetables vending. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 13,000 from her business activities.

Perjolen is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 12,000 was used to fund operations of her vegetable vending and had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 22nd loan in the amount of Php 14,000, which she intends to use on her vegetable vending business. Perjolen is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family--to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Liezel

texts.en:
Miss Liezel G. is a 27-year-old single woman. She is currently residing in Solinog, a barangay of Calamba municipality in Misamis Occidental, a province of northern Mindanao. She was appointed as a treasurer in their barangay and receives a monthly honorarium amounting to 3,500 PHP. Her other source of income comes from her business, in which she works on her computer entering data and printing documents. She makes a monthly net income of 1,000 PHP.

Liezel joined PMPC to apply for a 30000 PHP loan for her new business. The loan will be the first granted her by PMPC. The proceeds will be used to purchase a new computer for her business and personal use.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase one set computer

loans.name: Romeo

texts.en:
Romeo P., Jr. is from the town of Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 31 years old. Romeo is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Romeo owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing internet services and snack vending in the local community. Romeo has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Romeo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Romeo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Romeo is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be the second loan taken out by Romeo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en: Naseem is a wife of R. A. lives in a city named Borewala, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. Her husband has a business of vegetables. He sells vegetables on his cart by going to various places. His profession gives him earning approximately worth Pak Rs. 10,000 on monthly basis. Naseem also supports him by sewing clothes business. She utilizes her income to pay for the utilities. She is applying for a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to expand her husband’s vegetable selling business.

loans.use: To buy seasonal vegetables for vegetable selling business

loans.name: E.montealto's Group

texts.en:
Emelyn M. is 31 years old,  married and lives in the village of Villaflor. Emelyn is the leader of E. M.'s Group, a four-member group eligible for loans offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. 

Emelyn raises pigs. She has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month. In 2008 she joined PMPC to gain access to their financial services. Emelyn is requesting a loan of 25,000 PHP to purchase piglets to raise and sell in the future (this will be the fourth loan she has taken out from PMPC). She plans to use all additional revenue to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell.

loans.name: Bili

texts.en: Bili bakes and sells loaves of bread to earn a living. The demand for his loaves of bread is high and he is happy because he is the only person that bakes in his community and this means more profits and patronage. He hopes to own a world class bakery in the future. He is 45 years old, married with 4 children.  He is requesting for a loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more baking materials to boost his business. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baking materials to boost his baking business

loans.name: Chor

texts.en:
Chor S., 29 years old, is married and resides with her husband (pictured above) and two children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She stays at home to look after the children and do household chores while her husband works as a mechanic, earning an income of 10.60 USD per day to help cover the family expenses.

The family’s standard of living has improved since Chor’s husband has been in business. Chor is requesting a loan of 1200 USD to purchase mechanic's supplies to expand her husband current business. This is her second loan from CREDIT, which is partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: To buy mechanic's supplies to expand her husband's business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase a larger variety of goods

loans.name: Hope

texts.en:
Hope S. is a 58-year-old married woman who lives in Prk Mangga, Brgy Tabugon, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living through her general store and livestock business. Hope’s husband, Noe, is 59 years old and works as a farmer. They have 14 children aged between 19 – 42 years old with some of them having their own family while others work to help their parents. 

Hope joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in the general store and livestock businesses. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 12,000 from her business activities.

Hope is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 29,500 was used to fund operations of her general store and had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing, for her 18th loan, the amount of Php 29,500, which she intends to use on her general store and livestock businesses. Hope is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family--to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: additional working capital

loans.name: Sara

texts.en: Sara O. is 36 years old. She is married and has four children. In 1994 she started a salon after quitting selling vegetables, as a source of generating income so as to be able to provide basic needs to her children and have her own house. She restocks her salon after a fortnight with goods bought within Kisumu town. Due to the size of her business (which is very small), she has decided to request Ksh.20,000 in form of a loan so as to boost her business by increasing her stock. That will see her income increase with an increase in customers and she will be able to repay it while at the same time saving for future use.

loans.use: Increase her stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: Seng V., age 29, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia.  She is engaged in the business of buying rubber for sale, earning an income of $5 per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband is a worker at the rubber plantation, and he also buys rubber for resale, earning an income of $5 per day. Their standard of living has improved since they started these businesses, and V. is now requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase more rubber, a motorbike, and wood to repair the house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: To buy rubber for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase grains

loans.name: Sourou Monique

texts.fr: G. Sourou Monique est née vers 1955 et vit depuis huit ans au quartier Missessin à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à KATADJO Cyprien, Sourou Monique est mère d'un enfant qui est scolarisé. Le couple assure ensemble les charges familiales. Sourou Monique n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Il y a trois ans, en vue de contribuer à assurer les dépenses familiales, Sourou Monique a commencé la vente de nourriture (riz, accompagnée de sauce de tomate) à son domicile. Parallèlement à cette activité, Sourou Monique vend de l'huile d'arachide. Sourou Monique s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Face à la demande un peu plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Sourou Monique souhaite augmenter sa production alimentaire et son stock d'huile, afin de mieux répondre aux besoins de sa clientèle et de se faire plus de revenu. C'est ce qui l'amène à solliciter un quatrième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Sourou Monique G. was born around 1955 and has lived for the past eight years in the Missessin district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Married to Cyprien KATADJO, Sourou Monique is mother to one child who is at school. The couple covers the family expenses together. Sourou Monique attended primary school only. In order to contribute towards family expenses, Sourou Monique began three years ago to sell food (rice accompanied by tomato sauce) from her home. At the same time, she sells peanut oil. Sourou Monique gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. She is an old customer of ALIDé who repays her loans correctly. Faced with modestly increasing demand from her customers, Sourou Monique would like to increase her production of food and her stock of oil, in order satisfy better her customers' needs and to make more money. For this reason she is applying for a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cans of oil and bags of rice

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz M. is a 42-year-old married woman who supports her family through her general store and hog-raising business. She lives in Brgy Bangquerohan, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental with her husband and their 4 school-aged children who are between 1 and 16 years old. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and hog-raising businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 20,000.

Luz is now borrowing Php 15,000 so that she can buy additional products for her general store and feed for her pigs . This will be her 9th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 15,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Luz aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Isa

texts.en:
Isa is 48 years old who lives with his wife and their four children in Bayan-Olgii province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger (traditional Mongolian nomadic tent). One of his children is a university student and his youngest son, Augantai is a secondary school student. 

He has operated a clothes trading business with his wife since 1998.  They pay 70,000 tugrugs (~ $50) per month to rent a counter at a Tauba Trading Center.  Today Isa's working capital exceeds 3,000,000 tugrugs (~ $2111).  He is a very hardworking and enthusiastic person.  He is requesting a 2,800,000 tugrug (~ $1970) loan to purchase more inventory for his business.  Isa says, “I would like to purchase a new car for my family and to continue paying for my children's tuition fees.”

loans.use: Purchase more inventory.

loans.name: Tang

texts.en:
Tang M., 56, is widowed who lives with her child in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia.  Tang sells a variety of groceries from her home and earns about $5 per day to help cover family expenses. 

Tang's quality of living has been improving. She is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a printer and a photocopy machine for her child to start a business. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: Buy a printer and a photocopy machine.

loans.name: Dominga's Group

texts.en:
