Dominga B. is from the village of Catabban. She is 44 years old. Dominga is the group leader of a 14-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 'Dominga B.'s Group'.

Dominga is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Dominga owns & operates a furniture making business. The main source of income for the business comes from making & selling general household furniture for local businesses and community members. Dominga has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Dominga joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dominga has successfully repaid a previous loan of 28,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Dominga is requesting a new loan of 28,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Dominga from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings

loans.name: C3534 Ubwuzuzanye Group

texts.en:
Sada is 31 years old and is married with three children who are 2, 7 and 10 years old. She also takes care of one child who is 13 years old. Sada is the president of a group called Ubwuzuzanye and this group is well known in the business of selling women’s clothes. The hours of their business are from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Sada and her team are now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their business through adding the new business of selling men’s clothes such as jeans, shirts, etc. In addition, they will also start selling children’s clothes.

As the majority of the members of this group do not have their own houses, they hope that with the use of this loan, they will earn more profits, which in turn will allow them to individually achieve their goals.

loans.use: To add the selling of men's and children's clothes

loans.name: Nilpha

texts.en:
Nilpha D. is a 32-year-old married woman who supports her family through her general store and electronic reloading businesses.  She lives in Poblacion, Bacong, Negros Oriental with her 38-year-old husband, Jeffrey, who helps his wife in catering services. They have 2 children who are 10 and 3 years old.

Nilpha has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2001 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and electronic reloading business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 6,000.

Nilpha is now borrowing Php 12,000 so that she can expand her general store and electronic reloading businesses. This will be her 11th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 12,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Nilpha aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Ayeni

texts.en: I. is a fashion designer and he turns out lovely Nigerian and western designs for his customers. He loves this business because he makes his customers look good. He hopes to own a fashion house in the future. He has been in this business for a long time and he uses his experience in business to attract and retain more customers. He is 48 years old, married with 5 children. His wife also sells foodstuffs to support their home. He is requesting the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to boost his business.  He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to boost his business

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn Y. lives in the town of Brgy Sagasa, Ma-ao, Bago City.  She is married and has three children, ages 13 to 28.  To make a living, Marilyn owns & operates a 'sari sari' (variety) store.  The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community.  Marilyn has been engaged in this business for several years and earns approximately 12,000 Php a month from these activities.  The store is conveniently located on the side of a road traveled by tricycles (local three-wheeled transport vehicles) and school children alike.  She also has a small 1.25 hectare plot of land on which she plants rice.  

Marilyn joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from NWTF. Marilyn is now requesting a new loan of 12,000 Php which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  This will be the 6th loan taken out by the borrower from NWTF.  Marilyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to pay the tuition fee of her youngest child, who is in first year high school.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon."

loans.use: Additional capital for her 'sari sari' store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Minerva's Group

texts.en:
Minerva D. is from the village of San Pedro, Alicia, Isabela. She is 50 years old. Minerva is the group leader of a 17-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Minerva is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Minerva owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling candies, such as 'macapuno' and 'ube', to the local community. Minerva has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Minerva joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Minerva is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Minerva from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Mouy's Group

texts.en:
This is a small borrowing group of 4 members and Mrs. Mouy M. is the group leader. Mouy M., 34, is a grocery seller from her house in the village. She has a small store and runs her grocery business to earn her daily income. She is able to earn US$ 3 per day. She is a single woman without aN. children. To increase the amount of grocery items in her inventory and satisfy her customers, Mouy M. is requesting a loan to purchase more cooking ingredients, plastic goods, and cane goods for her store. 

The other three members of the group are:

Mrs. Paoch N., 46, a fish catcher, who is requesting a loan to buy more fishing accessories;

Mrs. Muoy S., 37, a fresh fish seller, who needs a loan to accumulate capital for her fish sales; and

Mrs. Chhay R., 41, a fisherman, who is asking for a loan to buy implements for fishing activities.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking ingredients, plastic goods, and cane goods for her store

loans.name: Merchde

texts.en:
Merchde is a 52-year-old married woman and mother of two children. She has been working as a tailor for the past 30 years; she runs this tailoring business from her home to help her husband with household expenses. In addition, after growing up and having their own work, her two children also help the parents with the family income and the big expenses. Merchde offers tailoring services for her customers and she also offers clothing-repair services. 

Today, Merchde is asking for a loan of US$ 1,200 to buy a new sewing machine instead of her used one to be able to deliver her tailoring products faster. And that way she will be able to take on more orders from her customers and earn more income.

loans.use: buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Josette

texts.fr: Née en 1961 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, D. Josette vit depuis trente ans au quartier Adjracomey à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Josette est divorcée de son mari et a un enfant à charge. L'enfant est scolarisé. Josette assure seule ses besoins et ceux de son enfant. Josette a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Depuis 20 ans, Josette vend divers liqueurs à Dantokpa, marché inernational du Bénin, et aussi à son domicile. Josette achète ses liqueurs toujours à Dantokpa. Josette sollicite pour une première fois l'appui financier de ALIDé, en vue d'agrandir son activité et d'acheter des liqueurs de grande marque pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1961 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin, Josette D. has lived for the past thirty years in the Adjracomey district of Cotonou, the economic capital of the country. Josette is divorced from her husband and has one child in her care. The child is at school. Josette provides for own needs and those of her child. She left school at secondary level. For the past 20 years Josette has sold a variety of liqueurs in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market, and also from her home. She always buys her liqueurs in Dantokpa. She is applying for a first loan from ALIDé in order to expand her activity and buy top brand liqueurs in order to satisfy her customers more readily.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various liqueurs

loans.name: Marites' Group

texts.en:
Marites L. is from the village of Cabaruan. She is 37 years old. Marites is the group leader of a 25-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 'Marites L.'s Group'.

Marites is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling bottled gasoline in the local community. Marites has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 36,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marites joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marites is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Marites from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lucita

texts.en:
Lucita C., is from the village of Baybay Triunfo, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old, married and has one adult aged-child.  To make a living, Lucita owns and operates a mini-grocery store.  She has been in business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Lucita joined PMPC to access financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Lucita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC to purchase additional products.  Lucita is now requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase additional groceries. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the living conditions of her family.
-----------------------------
About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase additional products for her grocery store.

loans.name: Lizabeth

texts.en:
Lizabeth A., is from the village of Solinog, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old, married and the mother of 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Lizabeth sells dry goods.  Lizabeth has been in business for over 5 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP a month.

In 2005, Lizabeth joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business activities.  She is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP to purchase additional stocks for her store.  This will be her 3rd loan from PMPC.  Lizabeth plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.
------------------------
About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase additional stock for her store.

loans.name: Asia's Group

texts.en:
Asia is a 38-year old talented lady. She prepares handmade items Chingair (It’s an urdu term used in Asian countries for keeping breads hot). This is a high demand in people and it looks attractive when the bread serves in it to the guests. She prepares veritable chingairs with different designs and colors. She prepares 5 sets per day and sells to the community and generates income.

Her husband name is M. A. who has a furniture selling business. He sells specifically chairs and tables in the market. He earns approximately Pak Rs. 10,000 on every month. Asia is applying for a loan to buy furniture to expand her husband’s business.

loans.use: To buy furniture (wooden chairs & tables)

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: To make a living, Virginia B. owns and operates a business venture preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. She is 43 years old, married and has three school-age children. They are from the village of San Mateo. Virginia has been in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2007, Virginia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be her sixth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Phan E., 60, lives in Srae Pou village in Takeo province.  She and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice.  Aside from farming, Phan is a silk weaver to support her family.  She wants to expand her business.  Phan has decided to ask for a loan to buy more silk to enlarge her business and to hire a weaver.  Phan is a mother of three children who are seamstresses in a garment factory. Her husband is on the right of the picture.

loans.use: Buy more silk to enlarge her business and hire a weaver.

loans.name: Raoufath

texts.fr: Née en 1977 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, O. Raoufath vit depuis une dizaine d'année au quartier Agbodjèdo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Raoufath est mariée à GBADAMASSI Latifou, un imprimeur, et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Raoufath vit seule avec ses enfants et assure seule leurs différents besoins. Raoufath n'a jamais été à l'école. Il y a près de sept ans que Raoufath mène comme activité la vente de tissus et des produits de beauté de façon ambulante. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomé au Togo, que Raoufath se ravitaille. Raoufath a bénéficié autrefois de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, et les a tous bien remboursés. Aujourd'hui encore, Raoufath sollicite un troisième prêt, en vue d'élever le niveau de son activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle. Par ricochet, Raoufath pourra se faire plus de revenu et améliorer son niveau de vie.
texts.en:
Born in 1977 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin, Raoufath O. has lived for around ten years in the Agbodjèdo district of Cotonou. Raoufath is married to Latifou GBADAMASSI, a printer, and has three children, all of whom are at school. Raoufath lives alone with her children and provides for their various needs herself. She has never been to school. She has for almost seven years been running a business selling fabrics and beauty products on a door-to-door basis. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market, and in Lomé in Togo. Raoufath has benefited in the past from two loans from ALIDé and repaid them correctly. Today, she is applying for a third loan with a view to increasing the level of her activity and to being able to respond better to her customers' demands. Indirectly this would allow her to make more money and improve her life.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric

loans.name: Kehinde

texts.en:
Kehinde is 53 years old and married with two children. His wife sells soup ingredients to help her husband. He produces and sells cellophane bags to earn a living. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. His greatest challenge is funds and he hopes to overcome the challenge. He hopes to grow his business to become bigger and stronger. He is requesting a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more cellophane bags to sell. 

Kehinde says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials to produce more cellophane bags to sell

loans.name: Rustica

texts.en:
Rustica C., 64, is from the village of Cagay-anon in the Philippines. She is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Rustica runs a general store.  Rustica has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000.00 PHP a month.

Rustica joined PMPC in February to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business. She is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell.  This will be her first loan from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue to save for future emergencies. 
----------------------------------
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Sugran's Group

texts.en:
Sugran is a wife of A. H.. Her husband runs a barber shop where he offers his services, cutting hairs and facial treatments.
He has been in this profession for the back 5 years. Sugran operates her decorative embroider business. She prepares embroider dresses on order. She obtains order from the cloth shops and gets income. She does this work to share the financial burden of her husband. They both feel happy to have each other in their lives. 

She is applying for a loan to buy items (chairs, scissors and shaving blades) to increase the income of her husband’s barber shop.

loans.use: To buy itmes for barber shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase used clothing

loans.name: Siham

texts.en:
Siham is a 58-year-old widow woman with two children, one of whom is still dependant. She has 25 years of tailoring experience. After the death of her husband, she started running a tailoring business from her home to raise her family with the support of her older employed child. The loss of her husband was hard for her; she has taken on all the responsibilities after his passing. She produces all types of clothing according to the customers' requests and she repairs torn clothes. 

Today, Siham is asking to borrow $1,000 to purchase a new sewing machine and improve her business productivity. She’s certain that the loan will be very helpful for her work.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Paciencia

texts.en:
Paciencia E. is from the village of Canibungan Daku, in the Philippines.  She is 69 years old, widowed and the mother of 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Paciencia cultivates fruit trees and sells fruit. Paciencia has been in this business for over 15 years.  She earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Paciencia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Paciencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase harvesting equipment.  She is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP o repair a ehicle used in the business.  This loan will be her 5th from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue to support her family. 
-----------------------------------------
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Repair a transport vehicle used in business.

loans.name: Imelda's Group

texts.en:
Imelda A. is from the village of Manaring. She is 42 years old. Imelda is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Imelda A.' Group.

Imelda is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Imelda owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling vegetables in the public market. Imelda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Imelda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Imelda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Riza's Group

texts.en:
Riza C. is from the village of Calatunan. She is 36 years old and the leader of a two member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the entire loan if either is delinquent or defaults.

To make a living, Riza owns and operates a sari-sari store (general store). Her husband as a carpenter.  Riza has been engaged in business for over 6 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Riza joined PMPC to access financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. 

Riza has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC.  Now she is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and for working capital.  This loan will be her 7th loan from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family. 
----------------------------------
About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase additional goods to sale.

loans.name: Phea

texts.en: Phea O. is 32 year old married mother of four who lives in Prey Phnhi village, in Takeo province. She is a vegetable seller and her husband is a construction worker.  They don't earn enough income to support their family.  Phea wants to began a silk weaving business and buy a cow for breeding.  With this loan, she hopes to increase her income to support her family.  One of Phea's children is a construction worker and the other three attend a local school.  Her husband is on the right of the picture.

loans.use: Buy silk and a cow.

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi M. is from the village of Sepac, Sapang Dalaga Misamis Occidental. She is 44 yeras old, married and blessed with 4 school-aged children. She cultivates and selling farm products.  Naomi has been in business for 15 years and generate a monthly net income of 4,000 to support her family.

In 2004, Naomi joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Naomi is requesting a new loan of 25,000.00 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her business. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Naomi from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.
---------------------------------
About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Additional capital for her farm.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Emily bakes and sells loaves of bread to earn a living. The demand for her loaves of bread is high and she is happy because she is the only person that bakes in her community and this means more profit and patronage for her loaves of bread. She hopes to own a world-class bakery in the future. She is 49 years old, married with 3 children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home.  She is requesting a loan amount of NGN 150,000 to purchase more baking materials to boost her business. She hopes to lift her business and family above poverty. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baking materials to boost her baking business.

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
35-year-old Roseline is married with 4 children. She lives in Lagos where she does her business; she sells frozen food, vegetable oil and drinks. She has been in the business since 2002 and has been doing fine. She hopes for great improvement and expansion in her business in future. This will also improve her family's standard of living.

She is requesting a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more frozen food, vegetable oil and drinks to sell and make more profit as well.  She plans for a brighter future for her children as she and her husband, who is also in business, use their income to educate the children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their huge support.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen food, vegetable oil and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Sokchan

texts.en:
Sokchan B. is a 27 year old married woman who lives in Ampil Lech village, in Takeo province.  She and her husband, Chantou, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. 

Aside from farming, Sokchan is a silk weaver.  The extra money helps to support her family.  She decided to ask for a loan to purchase silk for weaving and to buy fertilizer and gasoline to support her farm.  Sokchan is the mother of two children; one attends school and the other is 3 years old.  Her husband is on the right of the picture.

loans.use: Purchase silk for silk weaving and buy fertilizer and gasoline to support her farm.

loans.name: Lillian

texts.en:
Lillian is the single mother of two children aged 14 and 16 years. She is 35 years old and lives in a family home with her children. She is the head of her family with the responsibility of looking after her children.

Lillian operates a secondhand clothing business in Hoima, Uganda, and has been in the business for six years now. She first worked in a hotel (restaurant) as a waitress, after which she started selling clothing with the little capital she had. She dreams of educating her children and constructing her own residential home so as to shift from the family house.

Lillian’s clothing business was recently burned in a fire outbreak, that being the major hardship she has faced so far in her business. The loan funds are for purchasing clothes to sell at her stall in the market.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Evelyn's Group

texts.en:
Evelyn G. is from the village of Little Tadian. She is 22 years old. Evelyn is the group leader of a 11-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Evelyn G.'s Group.

Evelyn is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Evelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Evelyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en: Taiwo is 48 years old, married with 3 children. His children are doing well at school. Taiwo is a hardworking man and he sells for long hours to support his household. He sells drinks at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to be a major drink distributor in the future. He is requesting a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. He says thank you to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie is 37 years old and is married with four children who are 4, 8, 11 and 13 years old. Marie is known in the business of selling new clothes, mainly children’s clothes. She has been in this business for about five years and the hours of her business are from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day except Saturday.

Marie is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through adding a variety of styles such as men’s and women’s clothes. With this loan, she has a vision of wholesaling and retailing at the same time so that her revenue can be highly increased.

If successful, Marie hopes to continue building a secure future for her family and, additionally, she will help the people from her community by employing them.

loans.use: To add the sale of men's and women's clothes

loans.name: Magaret

texts.en:
Margaret saws and sells timber wood in Lagos. She likes doing the business because it does not involve perishable goods. Her costumers buy so well that she needs to expand her business. She needs extra capital to make this a reality; she is asking for a loan amount of NGN 120,000 to purchase more timber wood to sell. Margaret promises to pay back at the due date.

Margaret is 48 years old, married and has two children. They are between the ages of 17 and 27 years old and they support their mother in running the business along with their education. She thanks KIVA lenders for this great opportunity.

loans.use: To purchase more timber wood to sell.

loans.name: Claudine

texts.en:
Claudine is 35 years old and is married with seven children who are between 3 and 10 years old. She is well-known in the business of selling fruit which she starts very early in the morning, running until late in the evening hours. Claudine is very proud of her business as it allows her to provide daily food for her children.

Although Claudine has been in this business for about ten years, her original investment is still too low to earn enough profits which in turn can be used for further reinvestment in her business, improving her family situation, and saving for a better future. To end this, Claudine is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company which hopefully will help her to achieve a lot.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of additional fruit to sell

loans.name: Bandulatha

texts.en:
Bandulatha is a 46-year-old married woman who lives with her husband. She has four married daughters who live independently. She lives in the town of Hikkaduwa. She wants to earn some income, because she doesn't like to depend on others. She does not even like to depend on her husband.

Bandulatha has a coir (coconut-shell fiber) business, in which she takes the fibers of local coconuts and weaves them into household items like string, rope, and floor mats. She has one year of experience in this field.

Bandulatha has requested a 15,000 rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC to help expand the coir business. She is thankful to the BRAC organization. 

She is an active, honest and kind woman. Bandulatha and her husband cooperate on the business and make a very good team together.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy is a 43-year-old lady operating a restaurant in Hoima, Uganda. She is a single mother of five children aged 23, 20, 19, 16 and 13 years. She is the family’s breadwinner and her family lives in a rented house though she hopes to construct her own residential house.

Daisy has been in business for eight years. Having started with pancakes and tea as stock, she now offers food, tea and cold drinks in her restaurant. She says she aims at improving the ambience of her restaurant to a better standard. She intends to buy a refrigerator using the loan funds because she has been hiring the one for the business.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator to replace the one she has been hiring

loans.name: Mouniratou

texts.fr: T. Mouniratou est née en 1978 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à ALABI Djamiou, Mouniratou est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Mouniratou vit avec ses enfants et son mari au quartier Agbodjèdo à Cotonou, depuis dix ans. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges familiales. N'ayant pas été à l'école, Mouniratou  mène comme activité la vente de divers produits (café, lait, thé, conserves, pâtes alimentaires, sucre, vinaigrette, papiers hygiéniques, savons, etc.) à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Mouniratou s'approvisionne également dans le même marché. Mouniratou exerce cette activité depuis sept ans et avait bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Mouniratou souhaite renforcer son activité et augmenter son chiffre d'affaire. C'est pour cette raison que Mouniratou sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième prêt.
texts.en:
Mouniratou T. was born in 1978 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Djamiou ALABI and is the mother of four children, all in school. Since ten years Mouniratou has been living with her children and husband in the Agbodjèdo borough of Cotonou. The couple jointly shares family expenses. Not having attended school, Mouniratou has an activity of retailing various products (coffee, milk, tea, canned goods, pasta, sugar, salad dressing, toilet paper, soap, etc.) in Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. She gets her supplies from the same market. Mouniratou has been running this business for the past seven years and has already been granted two loans from ALIDé, both of which have been repaid in full. She now wishes to strengthen her activity and increase her turnover. This is why she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products (canned goods, pasta, soap, toilet paper, milk, coffee, etc.)

loans.name: Nusrat Parveen's Group

texts.en: Nusrat Parveen is a citizen of a city named Borewala, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan for the back 25 years. Her husband name is N. A. who is a carpenter by profession and makes furniture on order. He learn this art from his father because he was a very talented man. He has integrated his father's techniques into his own business, which has led to him having a good reputation in the market.  Now, his business has become a renowned business. Currently he received a large number of orders from his customers and to achieve them Nusrat is asking for a loan of worth Pak Rs. 20,000 so that her husband can purchase the required material and generate a good income.

loans.use: To buy material for furniture making business

loans.name: Yein

texts.en:
Yein N., 59, is a villager who lives in Srae Vong village, in Takeo province.  She and her husband, Mean, are farmers who own a piece of land to cultivate rice.  Aside from farming, Yein sells grocery and vegetable to support her family.

Yein asks for a loan to buy a motorcycle and to buy more vegetable to enlarge her business.  Yein is the mother of four children; three are seamstresses in a garment factory and the other one is a student in a local school.

loans.use: Buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon V. is a 48-year-old woman living in the town of Brgy Canonoy, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental.  She is married and has 5 school-aged children.  To make a living, Corazon owns & operates a fishing business.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community.  Corazon has been engaged in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 10,000 Php a month from these activities.

In 2005, Corazon joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Corazon has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 Php from NWTF. Corazon is now requesting a new loan of 15,000 Php which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell.  This will be the 8th loan taken out by the borrower from NWTF.  Corazon plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon."

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi O. is a 36-year-old nursery school teacher.  She also owns a mini-retail shop, a business she started in 2003. She has been teaching and at the same time running the mini shop to support her husband in providing for their two children.

In 2008, Naomi became a widow after the death of her husband; since then, she has been the sole breadwinner for the family. For her to be able to support her family effectively, she wants to expand her business and see her income grow and it is for the reason she has applied for a loan with KMET for 20,000 KES to use to increase her stock.

Her future goal is to see her children get quality education that will see them have a better life in future. She lives in Manyatta Kisumu.

loans.use: To increase her stock to boost her business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Abbas

texts.en:
Abbas is a 40-year-old married man with 3 school-age children. He has owned an electrical equipment and phones shop in his town since 2000. He sells phones, phone accessories and rechargeable cards. He sells, in addition, electric equipment. He took out a first loan from Ameen and he's very thankful for the result of the loan. He has been very reliable in his repayments to Ameen and has repaid on time.

And today, Abbas is asking for a bigger loan amount of $2,000 to purchase additional merchandise needed to increase his sales and thus his income.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise.

loans.name: Kalsoom's Group

texts.en:
Kalsoom is a wife of Mr. T. and lives in a city named Borewala, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. They both are very hard working. They operate their dairy business. They both get up early and get the milk from their cows. Kalsoom sells the milk in the community and her husband sells the milk to the milk shops. They charge Pak Rs. 35 for 1 litre milk. They get almost 15 to 20 litre milk from their cows which give them good profit.

Presently, they have two cows but they need of a loan to buy another cow to expand their milk selling business.

loans.use: To buy another cow for dairy business

loans.name: Beatha

texts.en:
Beatha is 36 years old and is married with one child who is 6 years old. Beatha is known in the business of selling new clothes, mainly clothes for children. She has been in this business for about twelve years and the hours of her business are from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day.

Beatha is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through adding a variety of styles such as men’s and women’s clothes. With this loan she has a vision of purchasing large bales for wholesaling and retailing at the same time so that her revenue can be much increased.

If successful, Beatha hopes to continue building a secure future for her family and, additionally, she will help the people from her community by creating jobs for them.

loans.use: To add a variety of styles such as men's and women's clothes

loans.name: Fevely

texts.en: Despite the many challenges Fevely B. has encountered in her life, she has remained strong and happy to be working so hard in helping her husband earn an income by growing her own hog fattening business. This is the only way she knows to earn money to support the needs of her family, especially her two children aged one and three years old, since she has not received a degree from a higher level of education that could get her employed in offices and a higher compensation. The loans she had received through her membership in ASHI have helped her a lot in growing her business and she now has greater profit. Thus, she is again requesting another loan from ASHI in order to sustain her small business until it will grow. She plans to sell pigs she has fattened for four months either slaughtered or alive to meat vendors in the market. Profits will be used to improve her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase pigs for fattening.

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
Rachael is a member in LAPO microfinance. She owns a shop where she sells drinks and plastics. She wants to buy more plastics and drinks to sell and make more profit. In order to achieve this, she is requesting a loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase more plastics and drinks to sell.

Rachael is 43 years old and married with 5 children. Her husband is a public servant and they all live in Lagos state, Nigeria.

loans.use: To purchase more plastics and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Gorrett

texts.en:
Gorrett is a 31-year-old single mother of three children, ages 12, 9 and 8 years. She looks after her four-person family. She hopes to educate her children and to finish her residential house. 

She operates a bar in Hoima Town, Uganda and has been in the business for four years. She was once a house maid, then worked in a restaurant and milk shop, after which she started her own bar business with the small capital from the savings she had accumulated. She hopes to improve the standards of her bar so as to attract more customers. 

The purpose of the loan is to construct a chicken house for a poultry business so she can diversify her sources of income.

loans.use: To build a chicken house for a poultry business.

loans.name: Najma's Group

texts.en: Najma is a wife of M. A. and lives in a city named Borewala, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan.  Her husband operates a tailoring center in the community. He can sew designer and non designer clothes. He earns approximately Pak Rs. 10,000 on monthly basis. Najma is applying for a loan to buy an electric sewing machine for her husband so he completes the order on time and earns good profit.

loans.use: To buy an automatic sewing machine

loans.name: Innocentia

texts.fr: A. Innocentia est née en 1969 à Agonlin, dans le département du Zou au Bénin. Mariée à KOUANOU François, Innocentia est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Innocentia vit ensemble avec sa petite famille au quartier Dogoudo à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique.  Il y a près de six ans que Innocentia s’est installée dans ce quartier. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Innocentia n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Depuis 15 ans environs, Innocentia vend du maïs et de la farine de manioc qu'elle produit elle-même, au marché Sékou à Allada. De façon secondaire, Innocentia vend également du fromage au soja. C’est au marché de Houègbo et de ALllada que Innocentia achète ses produits. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu déjà trois crédits, qu’elle a tous bien remboursés. Innocentia voudrait élever davantage le niveau de son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. C’est ce qui l’amène à solliciter un quatrième prêt.
texts.en:
Innocentia A. was born in 1969 in Agonlin, in the Zou Department of Benin. Married to François KOUANOU, she is the mother of four children, all having attended (or still attending) school. She lives with her little family in the Dogoudo borough of Allada, in the Department of the Atlantic. Innocentia settled here some six years ago. The couple jointly shares family expenses. Innocentia has never attended school, and for the past 15 years, she has been selling corn and cassava flour she makes herself at the Sekou market in Allada. As a second business she sells soja-based cheese. She gets her supplies from the Houegbo and Allada markets. She is a regular client of ALIDé, having already been granted three previous loans, all reimbursed in full. She wishes to increase her level of activity and improve her response to customer demand. This is why she is requesting a fourth loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy baskets of cassava roots and four bags of corn

loans.name: Olaide

texts.en: Olaide is 45 years old, married with 4 children. Her eldest child is 18 years old while the youngest child is 5 years old. Her children are excelling in school and this gives her joy. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports their household. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. To make a living, she bakes and sells pastries. She also sells crates of eggs at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to make her business more sustainable. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more baking materials to boost her business. She says thank you to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baking materials to boost her business.

loans.name: Florienne

texts.en:
Florienne is 45 years old and married. She has 2 children who are 12 and 20 years old.  Florienne is a proven entrepreneur who sells food in her village.  She has been in this business for about 13 years.  The hours of her business are from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day.

Florienne realized that her original investment was too low to earn more profits. She is now requesting a Kiva loan that will allow her to increase her sales, as well as her profits.  With this loan, Florienne hopes to start selling various fruits, because they are often purchased in her business area. With this additional business, which hopefully will attract many customers, Florienne will keep expanding her business with a vision of being financially stable.

loans.use: To buy fruit to sell

loans.name: Mehnaz's Group

texts.en:
Mehnaz is a citizen of a city named Borewala a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. She is a very hard working lady. She operates an embroider clothes business to generate income. Her income allows her to pay for the utilities but she also saves a part for the rainy days.

Her husband name is M. A. operates a timber selling business. He has been selling it for the back 10 years. He earns not only money but the respect as well. All of his customers come to him for purchasing because of his good dealing. 

Mehnaz is applying for a loan to buy timbers in bulk to expand her husband’s timber selling business.

loans.use: To buy timbers to sell

loans.name: Veronique

texts.en:
Veronique is 39 years old and she is still single. Veronique owns a restaurant in the Jabana Sector of the Gasabo District. She has been in this business for about 5 years. The hours of her restaurant are from 5 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Veronique is now requesting a Kiva loan to help her to paint the walls of her restaurant and her own house. In addition, she will purchase some equipment, mainly saucepans, new plates etc.  With this loan, Veronique hopes also to improve the quality service in her restaurant.  If it is completely successful, Veronique will start saving for her future and will keep an eye on her business for its sustainability.

loans.use: To paint her restaurant and house, and buy saucepans and new plates

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora is 49 years old and is married with four children: two boys and two girls. They live in Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone. Her first child is working; two are drivers and the last child is in school.

Dora sells fish and has been a LAPO, SL client for over two years.  She has taken out four previous loans and bought a van to transport her fish.

Dora wants a loan of 3,000,000 Leones to buy more fish and she intends to live a good life.

loans.use: Buy fish to sell.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a 28-year-old married woman with one child. She lives in a house of five people. She and her husband contribute to the welfare of the family. Her family currently resides in a rented house with the hope of finishing their own house by next year. 

Alice operates a salon in Hoima, Uganda. Before she had her salon business, Alice worked at her auntie’s salon, and then worked with a tobacco company, after which she started her own salon by using the savings she had and credit from Hofokam. She dreams of adding bridal services and a clothing section to her saloon. 

The purpose of the loan is to purchase braids, weaves, mirrors and a phone for her salon.

loans.use: To buy braids, weaves, mirrors and a phone for her salon.

loans.name: Annonciatha

texts.en:
Annonciatha is 42 years old and married, and she has 2 children who are 16 and 17 years old. Annonciatha is known as proven entrepreneur who sells charcoal wholesale and retail. This is her 8th successful year in this business which she runs from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Annonciatha realized that her business is hand-to-mouth, that is,eating without saving. She needs to request a Kiva loan through Vision Finance Company to expand her business by creating many sources of income from the same charcoal business, and to provide jobs to the people of her community. With this loan, Annonciatha hopes that her revenue will increase so she can save for her future and do her best for her children.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Viviane

texts.fr: Née en 1973 à Attotinga au Bénin, Y. Viviane est mariée à AMOUSSOU André, un tailleur, et est mère de sept enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Deux des enfants ne sont plus à la charge de Viviane et de son mari. Il y a près de 15 ans que la famille vit au quartier Dogoudo à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Viviane n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et porter une aide financière à son mari, Viviane vend du sel de cuisine et divers autres produits (conserves de tomates et de sardine, pâtes alimentaires, savons, condiments de sauce, etc.) à Allada. Viviane achète ses produits à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, et parfois à Allada. Viviane mène cette activité depuis dix ans et a obtenu déjà trois crédits de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus importante de sa clientèle, Viviane n'arrive plus à tous les satisfaire, et sollicite donc un quatrième prêt. Ce prêt lui servira à rehausser son activité pour mieux satisfaire la clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1973 in Attotinga in Benin, Viviane Y. is married to André AMOUSSOU, a tailor, and is the mother of seven children, all having attended (or are still attending) school. Two of the children are no longer under their parents’ care. For the past 15 years, the family has lived in the Dogoudo borough of Allada, in the Department of the Atlantic. The couple jointly shares family expenses. Viviane has not attended school. To meet her needs and help her husband financially, she sells kitchen salt and various other products in Allada (canned tomatoes and sardines, pasta, soap, sauce condiments, etc.). She gets her supplies from Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, and sometimes in Allada. Viviane has been in this line of business for ten years and has already been granted three loans from ALIDé, all of which were repaid in full. Facing an increasingly important customer demand, she is no longer able to satisfy all customers, and is therefore requesting a fourth loan. This loan will be used to bolster her activity to increase customer satisfaction.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 4 cases of canned tomatoes, 4 cases of pasta, and one ton of kitchen salt.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet T. has been a business woman operating different businesses since she dropped out of school when she was still a teenager. She started her current business, where she sells foodstuffs and some vegetables, in 1991. She buys her stock in Kibuye Market while she does her business and also lives in Manyatta Kisumu.

She is a mother of two children and at the age of 52 years she is working hard to be able to build her own house since she is a widow. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 KSH.

loans.use: To increase her stock.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Aina

texts.en:
Aina is 35 years old and married to her husband Mr. A. who is a businessman. They have no child yet. She resides in Lagos where she manages her 6-year-old business. She buys and sells groceries and drinks in wholesale and retail respectively.

Aina has a record of success in her business and has been able to save a little from profits she makes to assist her household and her siblings. She hopes to expand her business in future.

She is requesting a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell to maximize her profit in order to save and reinvest in the business for further expansion. Aina has been a member in LAPO microfinance for some years with a good repayment record. She thanks LAPO and Kiva lenders for their huge support.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Nathalie

texts.en:
Nathalie is 40 years old and married. She has six children between 3 and 20 years old.

Nathalie sells new clothes, mainly children's clothes. She has been in this business for about 5 years. Her business hours are from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Nathalie is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand her business bu adding a variety of styles such as jeans for old people and women's clothes. She expects to start selling children's shoes, because many of her clients have children.

loans.use: Adding a variety of styles to her clothing store

loans.name: Majed

texts.en:
Majed is a 38-year-old father of three sons and four daughters. Ahmad, his eldest son, works in carpentry while the rest are school students.

Majed's business is ten years old. He digs wells and holes for construction-supporting columns and cleaning old buildings' stones. The machines he uses need maintenance so he applied for a loan from FATEN for this purpose. He hopes that maintaining his machines will help him earn more money and allow him to purchase more advanced machines.

Majed says that working in this field in his small town Qalqilia is good but with the primitive machines he uses it's not rewarding regarding time management.

Majed appears in our offices in Qalqilia in the picture above.

loans.use: Machine maintenance

loans.name: Olatunde

texts.en:
Olatunde is 46 years old and is married with four children. His children attend school and this makes him happy. His wife is a caterer and she also supports their home.

Olatunde sells and repairs electronics to make a living. He is an honest and hardworking man and is so determined to excel in his business and family life. He is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more electronics to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electronics to sell

loans.name: Roland

texts.en:
Roland is a 34-year-old single man living with and taking care of his elderly parents.

Roland has been working as a carpenter for the past ten years, working on a freelance basis upon the request of the customers. Over the years, he has been able to make a good reputation and has gained a growing number of clients.

Today, Roland is requesting $1,200 to purchase carpentry tools because, after this long period in this occupation, he's planning to expand his business market and meet his clients’ requirements to keep his good reputation.

loans.use: To purchase carpentry tools

loans.name: Holboy

texts.ru: Саттаев Холбой проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 57 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Образование среднее. Более 40 лет занимается животноводством. Разводит скот у себя дома. Он в основном откармливает и продает скот. Вся его семья занимается этим видом деятельности. Кредит берет для закупа скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en:
Holboy S. lives in the Hamadoni district. He is 57 years old, married and has 6 children. He has a secondary education and has been involved in animal husbandry for over 40 years. Holboy breeds livestock at home. He primarily fattens and sells livestock. His whole family is involved in this business. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of livestock in order to increase its quantity.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Irene Akinyi

texts.en:
Irene Akinyi O. is a businesswoman who sells charcoal and eggs. She started this business in 2008 to be self-employed after leaving her sales and marketing job where she used to work in a pharmacy. She buys her stock mostly in Kibuye Market on a weekly basis and lives in Manyatta.

At the age of 30, Irene is married and has two children. She wants to expand her business and be a strong entrepreneur. She would like to obtain a loan of Ksh 20,000 that she will use to increase her stock to give her business a boost.

loans.use: To increase her stock to boost her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy two bags of flour, two jerrycans of peanut oil, and some school supplies.

loans.name: Muzamil

texts.en:
Muzamil is a 29-year-old man who is married to a housewife and has a 4-year-old child. He is the family’s breadwinner and lives with two people, his wife and child, in Hoima, Uganda. 

Muzamil has been operating a barber shop for eight years. Having worked as a ventilator constructor, he then worked in a barber shop, after which he set up his own shop by using the savings he had and a loan from Hofokam. He says he would like to shift the business to the central market where there are more customer opportunities. 

The loan will be to used to buy a motorcycle to ease his transport from home to work, because he lives far from his business.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to commute to work

loans.name: Claudine

texts.en:
Claudine is 35 years old and married, with 4 children who are between 4 and 12 years old. Claudine sells new clothes, mainly children's clothes. She has been in this business for about 4 years. Her business is open from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day.

Claudine is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand her business by adding a variety of styles, such as jeans and women's clothes. She will start selling jackets because they are highly demanded in her business area. With this business expansion, Claudine will, hopefully, earn more profits, which in turn, will allow her to build a secure future for her children and maintain her business.

loans.use: Adding a variety of styles such as jeans and women's clothes

loans.name: C3532 Abakunzi Group

texts.en:
Shemsa is 43 years old and married. She has 3 children who are between 1 and 3 years old. Shemsa is the president of a group called Abakunzi. This group is well known in the business of selling men’s shoes. The hours of their business are from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day except Saturday.

Shemsa and her team are requesting a Kiva loan to expand their shoe business by adding women’s shoes as well as children’s shoes. With this expansion, this group hopes to earn more profits which, in turn, will allow each member of the group to start saving for his future. Some of them hope to build their own houses, which they have dreamed of long before.

loans.use: To add women's and children's shoes

loans.name: C5197 Inkoramutima Group

texts.en:
Felicita is 33 years old and married. She has three children who are 3, 7 and 11 years old. Felicita is the president of a group called Inkoramutima. This group is commonly known in the business of sewing clothes. This is their fourth successful year in this business, which they run from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day.

Felicita and her team need to request a Kiva loan to buy additional sewing machines, including one over-sewing/over-casting machine and some clothing items needed in their business. With this loan, this team hopes to earn more profits which, in turn, will be used for the further reinvestment in their business. They hope to develop a sustainable business and build a secure future for their families. They also have a vision of rearing domestic animals, mainly cows, sheep and goats.

loans.use: Additional sewing machines, including one over-sewing/over-casting machine, and some clothing items

loans.name: Bolatito

texts.en:
Bolatito is a fashion designer and she designs lovely Nigerian and Western designs for her customers. She loves this business because she makes her customers look good. She hopes to own a fashion house in the future. She has been in this business for a long time and she uses her experience in business to attract and retain more customers.

Bolatito is 31 years old and is married with two children. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports their home. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to boost her business. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials

loans.name: Erick

texts.en:
Erick O. operates a butcher shop where he sells meat in Nyalenda, Kisumu. He started this business in 2009 after quitting tailoring which was not generating enough income for him to effectively support his family. He restocks daily, buying his stock from slaughterers in Rabuor.

Erick would like to expand his business so that he will be able to build his own house where he will live with his family and not have to pay rent. He would like to obtain a loan of Ksh 20,000.

Erick, 34 years old, is married and has one child.

loans.use: To expand his business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Damien

texts.en:
Damien is 35 years old and is married with two children who are 2 and 6 years old. He also takes care of two relatives who are 12 and 16 years old.

Damien is a self-employed businessman selling a variety of goods as his photo indicates. Among those goods, are included cosmetics products like body lotion, Colgate (toothpaste) and foodstuffs like rice, sugar, flour and cooking oil. His shop is open from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Damien is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business by purchasing a large quantity of sugar and rice, as they are highly in demand. With this large quantity he will also start wholesaling. In doing so, Damien hopes to earn more profits which in turn will allow him to renovate his house and continue paying school fees for his two relatives as well as building a secure future for his two children.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of sugar and rice

loans.name: Davlatmurod

texts.ru: Саттаев Давлатмурод проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 33 года. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Давлатмурод занимается животноводством. Он откармливает и продает скот. В этой области более 20 лет. Кредит берет для закупа мелко- рогатого скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en:
Davlatmurod S. lives in the Hamadoni district. He is 33 years old, married and has 5 children. His wife is a homemaker. Davlatmurod is involved in animal husbandry. He fattens and sells livestock. He has been working in this field for over 20 years. Davlatmurod is requesting the loan for the purchase of small livestock in order to increase its quantity.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of small livestock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: A. Monique

texts.fr: O. A. Monique est née le 09 Décembre 1985 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a environs 10 ans que Monique s'est installée au quartier Gbowèlè à Allada dans le département de l'Atlantique. Mariée à BOKO Lazare un menuisier, Monique est mère de deux enfants dont un est scolarisé. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Monique a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Il y a envions huit ans, afin de subvenir à ses besoins, Monique vend des cartes de recharges téléphoniques. De façon secondaire, Monique vend également du maïs. Monique achète ses produits à Allada, et les vend également dans la même ville. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu trois crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Monique voudrait renforcer son activité et accroître sa clientèle, ce qui lui permettra de se faire plus de revenu. Pour réaliser son projet, Monique sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un quatrième prêt.
texts.en:
A. Monique O. was born 9 December 1985 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Some ten years ago, she settled in the Gbowèlè borough of Allada in the Department of the Atlantic. Married to Lazare BOKO, a carpenter, Monique is the mother of two children of whom one attends school. The couple jointly shares family expenses. Monique interrupted school at the secondary level. To meet her needs over the past eight years, Monique has been selling phone recharge cards. As a secondary business, she also sells corn. She buys her products in Allada, and sells them in the same town. She is a regular client of ALIDé, having been granted three previous loans, all repaid in full. Monique wishes to reinforce her activity and expand her customer base, which will generate more income. To enable this to happen, she is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy phone recharge cards wholesale

loans.name: Madlene

texts.en:
Madlene, who has eight years of experience as a beautician, is a single woman, 35 years old, living with her parents.

Madlene opened a beauty salon in her home in 2005 and started receiving clients. She offers all kinds of beauty services: make up, manicure, pedicure, wax, laser, etc.

Madlene has already taken her first loan and she's very pleased with her decision to take another loan from Ameen. Over the course of her loan term, she has consistently repaid on-time and she has even repaid the full loan amount earlier than her scheduled end date.

Today, Madlene is requesting $1,200 to buy a new laser machine, very modern, so as to be always up-to-date in her market and to introduce all the new equipment for her customers.

In the future, Madlene would like to open a formal beauty salon for women.

loans.use: To buy a new laser machine

loans.name: Gerard

texts.en:
Gerard is 46 years old and is married with seven children who are between 6 and 18 years old.

Gerard is a hardworking businessman known in the business of baking breads for sale. He has been in this business for about five years and the hours of his business are from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Gerard has an idea of expanding his business meaningfully through purchasing a large quantity of flour so that he can increase the quantity of produced breads to the extent that he can even start wholesaling. To this end he is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that his sales as well as the profits can be increased.

The more Gerard’s business keeps growing, the more he will save for his future and continue taking care of his family.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of flour

loans.name: Rukhsana Tufail's Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana Tufail lives in a city named Borewala, Pakistan. She operates a sewing clothes business to meet the financial expenses of her family. Her business gives her earning approximately Pak Rs. 6,000 every month. 
Her husband name is M. W. who sells cosmetics on different shops in the market. He purchases cosmetics from city named Lahore because of its cheap rates and good quality items. Now he wants to diversify his business by selling some more items such as (hair dryer, hair colors etc) so that he reaches on more customers and generates good profit on it.

loans.use: To purchase more items for cosmetics selling business

loans.name: Monicah

texts.en:
Monicah O. is 37 years old. She is married and has six children.

Monicah started her tailoring business in 1998 after managing to buy a sewing machine. Before, she used to make table mats to sell.

With her business, Monicah has been able to generate income in order to provide for her family with little help from her husband. She lives in Nyalenda, Kisumu, Kenya, and buys her stock within the town every fortnight.

Monicah wants to expand her business in future and to do this she needs something to boost her business with. It is for this reason she has applied for a loan of Ksh 20,000 to increase her stock so that she will see her income increase.

loans.use: To increase her stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gagik

texts.en:
Gagik S. is 55 years old and lives in Chapni village, Kapan area, with his wife and two children: a son and a daughter.

Gagik’s family members are all engaged in beekeeping which, in summer time, takes about fourteen hours per day. Thanks to beekeeping, Gagik solves his family needs. Also he sells bees to fellow villagers and helps them to take care of them.

Gagik asks for a 700,000 AMD loan to buy wax papers, frames and sugar for his beehives.

loans.use: To buy wax papers, frames and sugar for his beehives

loans.name: Léticia Rose

texts.fr: H. Léticia Rose est née le 23 Août 1975 à Houègbo dans le département de l'Atlantique. Il y a près de 20 ans que Léticia Rose vit au quartier Ahito à Allada. Mariée à TELLA Patrick, Léticia Rose est mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Léticia Rose vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple se partage les différentes charges familiales. Léticia Rose n'a pas été à l'école, mais a appris la couture, activité qu'elle exerce à plein temps et qui lui procure des revenus. Parallèlement, Léticia Rose vend divers objets de mercerie dans son atelier à Allada. Léticia Rose s'approvisionne à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a environs trois ans que Léticia Rose exerce cette activité. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui effectue bien les remboursements de ses crédits. Léticia Rose sollicite un quatrième prêt, afin d'augmenter un peu plus le stock de ses produits et de mieux répondre à la demande des clients.
texts.en:
Léticia Rose H. was born on 23rd August 1975 in Houégbo in the "département" (administrative district) of Atlantique. For almost 20 years Léticia Rose has lived in the Ahito district in Allada. Married to Patrick TELLA, she is mother to four children who are all at school. Léticia Rose lives with her children and husband. The couple share the various family expenses. Léticia Rose did not go to school but learned how to sew and now does this full time to procure herself an income. At the same time she sells various haberdashery products in her workshop in Allada. Léticia Rose gets her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. She has been carrying out this activity for around three years. She is an old client of ALIDé who repays her loans correctly. She is applying for a fourth loan in order to increase her stock a little and also in order to be able to respond better to customer demand.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of six rolls of fabric, 10 boxes of embroidery thread, 50 meters of satin, 10 dozen sewing threads

loans.name: Parveen Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Parveen Akhtar is a very hardworking lady. She operates her decorative embroider business. Her clientele base is women. She prepares their dresses and earns good income. She is very committed and returns the clothes on fixed dates. Her nature helps her to maintain her customers.
