Her husband name is M. M. who has a medicine selling business. He sells medicines to the medical stores and earns income. Presently, Parveen is applying for a loan to buy medicines to expand her husband’s medicine selling business.

loans.use: To buy medicines to sell

loans.name: Rael Achieng

texts.en:
Rael Achieng O. operates a food kiosk (hotel) in Manyatta, Kisumu, Kenya. She started this business in 2009 since she was tired of being just a housewife and wanted to support her husband in providing for their three children as well as to be economically independent.

Rael buys her stock in Kibuye market weekly but would like to expand her business so that she could be doing this more often and in larger quantities to boost her income. She would like to obtain a loan of Ksh 20,000 to increase her stock.

Rael is 23 years old and has a dream of building rental houses and educating her children.

loans.use: To increase her stock to boost her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rasheed

texts.en:
Rasheed has a grinding machine that he uses to grind foodstuffs for his customers. He loves this business because he renders services to his customers. He has been in this business for ten years and he hopes to expand it.

Rasheed is 34 years old and is married with two children. His children attend school and this gives him joy. His wife sells shoes to also support her home.

Rasheed is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase another grinding machine to boost his business. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding machine to boost his business

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela A. is a 20 year old hard working, married, mother of one child. After finishing a tailoring course in 2009, she started a grocery store as an income generating activity and not a tailoring shop due to the limited capital she had at that time.

Pamela buys her stock in Kibuye market, Kisumu once every two days while she stays in Nyalenda Kisumu. She would like a a loan of Ksh.20,000 to be able to increase her stock and boost her business so as increase her income. Her dream is to expand her business and to be able to educate her child.

loans.use: To increase her stock.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Imad

texts.en:
Imad is a 42-year-old married man with four dependent children. Since 2000, he has owned a small tailoring shop in his town. He has been involved in this occupation for the past twenty years and makes a variety of products to offer his clients. Imad had profits from a first loan from Kiva and it was sufficient to fulfill his business objectives for the past year. He has been very punctual with his repayments to Kiva partner Ameen and he repaid his loan on time. 

Today, Imad is requesting to borrow $1,500 to purchase a new sewing machine in order to be able to take more orders and expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Zarina's Group

texts.en:
Zarina is from a city named Borewala, Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines.
Her husband name is M. N. who is a driver and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). She operates a sewing clothes business to share the financial burden with her husband. They both earn approximately Pak Rs. 15,000 on every month. This amount helps them to manage the financial expenses and to fulfill the needs of their children.
Currently, She is applying for a loan to repair her husband’s auto-rickshaw because its engine is creating problem and if it gets seized they will be faced the financial crises.

loans.use: To repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Anna Akinyi

texts.en:
Anna Akinyi O. operates a hotel (term used for a basic restaurant) in Dunga, Kisumu, Kenya. She started this business in the year 2000. Previously, she sold vegetables as a source of income.

She is 31 years-old and married with four children and has been instrumental in supporting her husband in providing for the family. She would like a loan of Ksh.20,000 to be able to increase her stock and expand her business in order to achieve her dream of her family having a house of their own where they no longer pay rent and will therefore be able to save enough for their children’s future education.

loans.use: To increase her stock.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Adjowoa

texts.fr:
Cette dame exerçait le métier de la couture dans son propre atelier. Plus tard elle a trouvé goût à un autre commerce qui est celui de commerce de produits d’alimentation générale. Elle a alors abandonné la couture au profit de la vente de produits d’alimentation générale qui lui réussit bien, voulant agrandir son commerce elle sollicite un prêt lui permettra de s’approvisionner en produits d’alimentation générale ainsi elle réalisera de grosses recettes.
Elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier de Lomé appelé  Hedzranawoé, avec son revenu elle participe aux dépenses du foyer.
texts.en:
Adjowoa used to be a seamstress with her own shop. Later she found she liked selling general food products. She thus stopped her work as a seamstress and began to sell food products. She has been successful and now wants to grow her business. For this purpose she is requesting a loan to purchase general food products and thus bring in a lot of money. She is married and the mother of 4 children. She lives with her family in the Hedzranawoé neighborhood of Lomé. With her income she is able to contribute to paying the household expenses.

Translated from French by Alex J, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase general food products

loans.name: Ulfat's Group

texts.en:
Ulfat is a wife of B. A. and they both live in a city named Borewala, Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines.
Her husband is a mason and has twenty-five years of experience in this profession. They are not an educated but they want to raise their children: two boys and one girl with good education. Her husband works hard to achieve the dream for their children. 
She is applying for a loan to buy mason tools so he performs his work more effectively and generates good income.

loans.use: To buy mason tools

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana is a mother of 5 sons. Four of them work in different professions and help take care of the household expenses while their father is a contractor. Susana has plenty of free time which she wants to use in doing something she likes.

Susana applied for a loan from FATEN as she is in the process of opening her own clothes store in Ramallah city.  She will use the loan to pay a part of the down payment to rent the store.

Susana hopes that her store will prosper soon and she'll be able to have her own source of income. Susana is in the picture above.

loans.use: Opening a clothes store

loans.name: Selah Atieno

texts.en:
Selah Atieno A. is 45 years-old. She is married and the mother of five children. She also takes care of two orphans left behind after the death of her daughter. With her husband not having a stable job, Selah works hard to be able to help her husband in supporting their family. She operates a hotel (a type of basic restaurant) based at Nyamasaria, Kisumu, Kenya where the family also stays.

To be able to expand her business, Selah would like a loan of Ksh. 20,000 to boost her business and to be able to increase her income. Her goal is to see all the seven children under her care get an education that will guarantee them a bright future.

loans.use: To increase her stock.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Dehoekin

texts.fr:
En 2000, cette femme s’est lancée dans le commerce de céréales qui sont très utilisées dans la cuisine togolaise. Elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays comme cela le coût d’achat lui revient moins chère ce qui lui permet de réaliser sur la vente de grands profits. son stock de céréales est en baisse, elle souhaite se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 04 sacs d'haricots, 4 sacs de maïs et divers.
Elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants
texts.en:
In 2009 Dehoekin started a business selling grains, which are used a lot in Togolese cooking. She purchases grains inland because it is cheaper for her and she is thus able to make higher profits on her sales. Her stock of grains is currently low and she would like to buy more supplies. For this reason she is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase 4 sacks of beans, 4 sacks of corn and other supplies. She is married and has 4 children.

Translated from French by Alex J, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase grains

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of three bags of rice, two cans of peanut oil and a box of spaghetti

loans.name: Nike

texts.en: Nike sells rechargeable phone cards and office stationery at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to expand her business. She has been in this business for three years and is making much progress in her business. She is 33 years-old and married with four children. Her children are progressing in school and this gives her joy as a mother. Her husband is an interior decorator and he also supports their home. She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase rechargeable phone cards to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase rechargeable phone cards to sell.

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela sells groceries and tailoring materials to make a living in Lagos, Nigeria. She is a hardworking woman; she opens her shop every day of the week and she is customer-friendly. She wants to sell her goods both wholesale and retail in order to meet her customers' demands and make more profit.

Angela is asking for a loan of 80,000 nairas to purchase more groceries and tailoring materials to sell. This will enable her to save and help her husband in keeping the home.

Angela is 35 years old and married with three children. Her family lives in Lagos where she manages her four-year-old business. She expresses her gratitude to lenders for their financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Chandani

texts.en:
Chandani is a 47-year-old married woman living with her husband and three daughters. They all help her business with support. They live in the town of Hikkaduwa.

Chandani has an agricultural business. With this business, she is providing good support to her family. She helps to handle the family expenses instead of relying just on her husband's income. Chandani has been doing this business for a long time, and this will be her third loan from BRAC.

Chandani has requested a 35,000 LKR loan from BRAC to help her agriculture business.

Day by day Chandani is working to earn increased income with financial support from BRAC. She hopes to be self-dependent, as she makes strong financial decisions and is a very responsible woman. Ultimately, she hopes to renovate her house in near future with her increased income.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Oluwafemi

texts.en:
Oluwafemi sells rechargeable phone cards at retail prices to his customers. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers.  He has been in this business for 10 years. He is making much progress and hopes to expand his business. 

Oluwafemi is 33 years old and single without children. He is requesting a loan of 70,000 nairas to purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Akou

texts.fr: Agée de 40 ans, cette femme exerce depuis 2000 le métier de la couture dans son propre atelier qu’elle a ouvert à Vakpossito qui est un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé. Pour accroître ses recettes, elle a associé à son commerce la vente de  tissus Bazins qu’elle expose parfois devant son atelier pour attirer ses clients. La vente de bazins lui réussit bien elle souhaiterait l’agrandir c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 15 bazins de grande qualité.
texts.en:
Akou is 40 years old and since 2000 she has been a seamstress with her own workshop that she opened in Vakpossito, a suburb of Lomé. To increase her income, she expanded her business to sell Bazin fabrics, which she sometimes hangs outside of her workshop to attract customers. The sale of Bazin fabrics has been successful and she would like to grow that part of her business. For this reason she is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase 15 pieces of high-quality Bazin fabric.

Translated from French by Alex J, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Bazin fabric

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of ten containers of oil and four bags of rice

loans.name: Olalekan

texts.en:
Olalekan is a fashion designer and he makes lovely Nigerian and western designs for his customers. He loves this business because he makes his customers look good. He hopes to own a fashion house in the future. He has been in this business for a long time and he uses his experience to attract and retain more customers. 

Olalekan is 42 years old and married with four children. His wife is a tailor and she also supports their home. He is requesting a loan of 70,000 nairas to purchase more tailoring materials to boost his business.  He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials

loans.name: C2875 Group

texts.en:
Marie Louise M. is the group representative of five members, each with a different business. She was born in 1983 and is married with two children. Her husband is a driver and they both work hard for their family.

Marie Louise owns a small shop which sells different kinds of products. The hours of her business are from six in the morning to six in the evening every day, even during the weekend. This is her 4th successful year in her business.

Marie Louise and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses through purchasing more products such as salt, cassava flour, bread and so on. With this loan, the group members have the target of improving their family situations through saving money for their future and paying the school fees of their children.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Yinka

texts.en:
Yinka is 42 years old, married with 4 children.  His children attend school and this makes him a happy father.  He hopes that his children become graduates in the future. 

His wife sells clothes and she also supports their home. 

Yinka sells and repairs electronics to make a living. He is an honest and hard working man.  Yinka is determined to excel in his business and family life.   He is requesting a loan of N80,000 to purchase more electronics to sell.  He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase electronics to sell.

loans.name: Marie Anne

texts.fr: H. Marie Anne est née le 02 Juillet 1966 à Allada dans le département de l'Atlantique. Marie Anne vit depuis 40 ans à Sékou à Allada. C'est une veuve qui est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés et vivant encore à sa charge. Marie Anne n'a jamais été à l'école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Marie Anne vend depuis 21 ans environs, des ustensiles de cuisine en plastiques et des bassines à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Marie Anne vend également du maïs. Marie Anne s'approvisionne à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, et dans le Nord du Bénin. Marie Anne a déjà obtenu auprès de ALIDé, deux crédits qu'elle a tous bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Marie Anne voudrait renforcer son activité et par conséquent se faire plus de revenus. C'est pour cette raison que Marie Anne sollicite un troisième prêt.
texts.en:
Marie Anne H. was born on July 2 1966 in Allada in the Atlantique department of Benin. For the last 40 years she has been living in Sékou in Allada. She is a widow and a mother of three children, all of whom went to school and are still under her care. Marie Anne never attended school. In order to support her family, she has spent the last 21 years selling plastic cooking utensils and bowls from her home. On the side, Marie Anne also sells corn. She gets her supplies form Cotonou (the economic capital of Benin) and in the North of Benin. Marie Anne already obtained two loans through ALIDé which she reimbursed. Faced with growing demands from clients, Marie Anne would like to augment her sales and in the process, increase her revenues. For this reasons, Marie Anne is asking for a third loan.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of plastic cooking utensils

loans.name: Kemi

texts.en: Kemi sells rechargeable phone cards at retail prices to her customers.  She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction she has with her customers.  She also hopes to expand her business.  Kemi has been in this business for 3 years and she is making a lot of progress. She is 28 years old, single with no children. She's an honest and hard working lady.  Kemi is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell.

loans.name: C2857 Abadahemuka Group

texts.en:
Theoneste is the group leader of four members, each with a different business. He was born in 1988 and is married with one child. His wife does not work.

Theoneste sells different kinds of clothes. The hours of his business are from six in the morning to six in the evening. This is his 4th successful year in his business of selling clothes.

Theoneste and his group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses through purchasing a variety of clothes. This, in turn, will allow them to sort out their personal problems concerning their businesses as well as support their families.

Theoneste and his group expect to earn more profits which will help them to save money for their children.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of clothes to sell

loans.name: Favour

texts.en:
Favour is business a woman who sells groceries and drinks at retail prices.  She has been in business for four years. She hopes to improve and expansion her business.

She is requesting the sum of NGN 100,000 as a loan to purchase more groceries, food stuff and drinks to sell. This will attract more customers, reduce costs per item on the wholesale level and increase her profits. 

Favour, 43, is hard worker, married with 2 children.  They are 15 and 17 years old.  She hopes to support their education. They live in Lagos State, Nigeria.  She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their assistance.

loans.use: Purchase more groceries, food stuff and drinks to sell.

loans.name: A. Pétronille

texts.fr: G. A. Pétronille est née le 06 Juin 1975 à Allada dans le département de l'Atlantique. Mariée à HOUNDJEMON Wilfried, Pétronille est mère de quatre enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. La famille vit au quartier Gbégamey à Allada, depuis dix ans. Le couple assure ensemble les charges familiales. Pétronille n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Depuis dix ans, Pétronille vend divers condiments de sauce (tomates fraîches, oignons, piments, etc.), ainsi que des savons et de l'huile au marché de Allada. Pétronille s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Pétronille a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, et les a tous bien remboursés. Pétronille sollicite un autre prêt, en vue de reconstituer son stock de produits et de mieux répondre aux exigences des clients, et par ricochet se faire plus de revenu.
texts.en:
A. Pétronille G. was born on June 6 1975 in Allada in the Atlantique department of Benin. Married to Wilfried HOUNDJEMON, Pétronille is a mother of four children, a few of whom are educated. The family has been living in the Gbégamey neighborhood in Allada for the past 10 years, and share the family responsibilities. Pétronille only attended primary school. For the past ten years, she has been selling a variety of ingredients used in sauces (fresh tomatoes, onions, peppers, etc) as well as soaps and oils in the Allada market. Pétronille gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She has already benefitted from two loans from ALIDé, both of which she has reimbursed in due time. She is asking for another loan in order to augment her stock of products and better address the demands of her clients and, through this, increase her revenues.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase baskets of tomatoes, peppers and 8 boxes of soaps

loans.name: Abiodun

texts.en:
Abiodun sells loaves of bread to make a living, in Ibadan.  She is a hard working woman, selling many hours each day to make her business more sustainable. 

She loves her business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers.  Abiodun hopes to own a bakery in the future. She is 38 years old, married with 5 children.  Her eldest child is 17 years old. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their family.  She is requesting a loan of N70,000 to purchase more loaves of bread to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more loaves of bread to sell.

loans.name: Sriyani

texts.en:
Sriyani is a 27-year-old married woman living with her husband and one child. She is living in the town of Hikkaduwa, Sri Lanka.

Sriyani has a business that consists of making and selling dresses. Her mother is living with the family, and she provides support for Sriyani’s business.

After attending school, Sriyani got started doing this business. She is educated and is a young lady. She can demonstrate strong leadership for any group and is a good team worker. She does her job on time and is a very honest lady. 

Sriyani is seeking a 40,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to expand her business. Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy more cloth for dressmaking

loans.name: Monsura

texts.en:
Selling of apples and cooking oil is a business activity that Monsura really enjoys.  She hopes to grow her business so it becomes bigger and stronger. 

She loves her business because of the profits that she makes.  This is the high season for her business and she hopes to have more customers.  Monsura is 45 years old, married with 4 children.  Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home.  She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more apples to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more apples to sell.

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is married with two daughters. She and her husband run a store that sells vegetable seeds, light-shades for greenhouses, crop protection supplies and farming tools. Olga has been in this business for ten years.  

Her business is in a convenient location and has a big assortment of inventory.  Olga has regular clients and fair prices. She is requesting a loan of 13,100 UAH to purchase more inventory. Olga's would like to sell small tractors, tillers, cultivators, etc.

loans.use: Purchase more inventory.

loans.name: C2350 Tuzamurane Group

texts.en:
Francine is 31 years old and is married with four children aged between 3 and 9. She also takes care of one dependent who is 17 years old. Francine’s husband is driver.

Francine is into tailoring as well as being group leader of this group called Tuzamurane, which contains six members. Francine uses her sewing machine and has been in this business for eight years. The hours of her business are from eight in the morning to eight in the evening, every day except Sunday.

Francine and her group are requesting a loan simply because they need to get ahead in their business through buying the new sewing machine. Most of them are tailors but one has a public phone business.

With this loan Francine and her group hope to obtain more profits which will allow them to change their family situations through providing everything they need.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary has a shop where she sells microwaves, washing machines, fans, and other items in order to make a profit. With the profit from the business, she can save a little money and assist her husband in running the home. Her husband is a pastor, and he is also trying to meet his financial responsibilities.

Mary hopes to expand her business. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN in order to purchase more microwaves and washing machines to sell.

Mary is 48 years old and married with four children. She lives in Lagos, Nigeria. She works hard to assist her husband in meeting the family's needs. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more microwaves and washing machines to sell

loans.name: Hadijah

texts.en: Hadijah A. is thirty-nine years old, married and blessed with a son.  She sells cloth has been doing so for over two years.  Hadijah is using this loan to purchase more cloth to expand and increase sales.  She also offers tailoring services. Her hope is to expand her business.

loans.use: Purchase more cloth to expand and increase the sales.

loans.name: Fumilayo

texts.en: Fumilayo sells rechargeable phone cards and male undergarments at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to expand her business. She has been in this business for eight years, and she is making much progress in her business. She is 28 years old and married without children. She is an honest and hardworking woman. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 70,000 NGN in order to purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Delphine

texts.fr: S. Delphine est née le 20 Novembre 1976 à Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin. Mariée à GUEDOU Bertin, Delphine a trois enfants à charge. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés et vivent avec le couple au quartier Agontinkon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a trois ans que Delphine s'est installée dans ce quartier. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et apporter un appui financier à son mari, Delphine vend des tissus (bazins, hitarget, etc.) ainsi que des costumes par le système de distribution. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomé au Togo que Delphine se ravitaille. Delphine voudrait rehausser le niveau de son activité et mieux répondre aux multiples exigences de sa clientèle. C'est pour cette raison que Delphine sollicite pour une première fois, de prêt à ALIDé.
texts.en:
Delphine S. was born on 20 November 1976 at Ouidah, a historic city in Benin. Married to Bertin Gouedou, Delphine is responsibile for three children, all of whom are educated and live with the couple in the Agontinkon neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Delphine moved to this neighborhood three years ago. The couple work together to take care of the family. In order to take care of her needs and to bring financial support to her husband, Delphine sells typical African-style cloth (such as Bazins, Hitarget) and suits through the distribution system. She stocks up on materials in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, and at Lomé in Togo. Delphine would like to increase the level of her activity and respond better to the multiple demands of her clients. It is for this reason that Delphine is soliciting, for the first time, a loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cloth

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Selling eggs is a business activity that Grace loves so much. She hopes to expand her business. She loves her business because of the profits that she makes. This is the high season for her business, and she hopes to attract more customers. She has been in this business for one year. She is 48 years old and married with five children. Her husband is a pastor, and he also supports their home. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 70,000 NGN in order to purchase more crates of eggs to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of eggs to sell

loans.name: Mariama

texts.fr: Mariama C. est une femme de 33 ans, elle est veuve et mère d'un enfant en charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DIBANE COUNDA depuis 2ans et demi. Elle est vendeuse de fruits de saison, elle achète le produit en grande quantité pour revendre au détail dans son quartier. Ses bénéfices lui permettent d'amélioration les conditions de vie de son enfant et de payer sa scolarité.
texts.en:
Mariama C. is a 33-year-old woman. She is a widow and the mother of one child. She has been a member of Dibane Counda's Banc Villageois for two and a half years. She sells seasonal fruits, she buys them in bulk in order to resell them at retail price in her neighborhood. Her earnings allow her to improve her child's living conditions and to pay for schooling.

Translated from French by Jessalyn Pinneo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building and promoting her business

loans.name: George Mwaura

texts.en:
George is 23 years old and single. He rears pigs and sells them to butcheries in the Kinoo Trading Center.  This is his primary business and he has been doing this for the last two years.  George is also a part-time construction worker to raise extra income.

He found out about KADET through some business friends who were members. This is his first loan with KADET.  With this loan, George plans to buy more piglets to raise and sell.

loans.use: Buy piglets.

loans.name: Alice

texts.fr: Née en 1953, C. Alice vit depuis 21 ans au quartier Sètovi à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Alice est mariée à MITOUN Victorin, un électricien, et est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Alice n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Alice vend des tissus, et aussi du charbon de bois à son domicile. Alice achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, mais également à Houègbo et à Sékou. Alice exerce cette activité depuis huit ans et a obtenu une fois déjà de prêt à ALIDé. Alice a bien remboursé le crédit. Alice sollicite un deuxième crédit, afin de rehausser le niveau de son activité et de mieux répondre aux demandes de ses clients.
texts.en:
Born in 1953, Alice C. has been living for the last 21 years in Sètov in Cotonou, economic capital of Benin. She is married in Victorin Mitoun, an electrician, and mother of two children that are both educated. The couple work together to address the needs of the family. Alice did not attend school. To address her needs, Alice sells cloth and wood coal from her home. She purchases her materials in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, as well as in Houègbo and Sékou. Alice has been doing this work for the last eight years and received one loan previously from ALIDé, which she reimbursed. Alice is asking for a second loan, in order to increase her activity and better respond to the demands from her clients.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cloths

loans.name: Luba

texts.en: Luba is widowed with two children. She sells women's clothing in a small store in Korolyovo town, Western Ukraine.  She has been in business for 5 years. Her net profit is 4,000 UAH per month.  This is her only source of income for her family.  She lives with her daughter in house she owns.  Luba would like to borrow 12,000 UAH to increase her clothing assortment.  She hopes to generate additional income to support her household needs.

loans.use: Increase assortment.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increasing product turnover

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 23-year-old single man living with his family. He has been in phone sales for four years and in January 2010, he opened a small phone-sales shop. He sells mobile phones and he also repairs all type of phones. Ali is very glad because he finally started his own business to build his career. 

In order to reinforce his new business, Ali is requesting to borrow $1,200 to increase his inventory and buy new phone models to attract more clients and be always able to fulfill their requests.

loans.use: Increase his inventory and buy new phone models

loans.name: Bitty

texts.fr: Madame Bitty D. est une femme mariée de 53 ans. Elle vit dans la localité de Baye Laye plus précisément dans le quartier de Wakhinane. Elle est membre de l’institution U-IMCEC caisse  de Baye laye depuis avril 2008. Elle y a déjà bénéficié de 2 prêts antérieurs.  C’est une veuve qui gere9 enfants sous son toit  et dont l’âge varie entre 16 et 30 ans. Madame D. s’active dans la vente de petit déjeuner  chez elle le matin. Parfois elle pratique la vente d’articles de femmes comme les boucles d’oreille et autres. Elle capitalise une expérience de 15 ans dans le petit commerce.  Rester oisive  ne constitue pas une option pour elle. Et c’est la raison pour laquelle elle s’est orientée vers le commerce ce qui au moins pourra l’aider à résoudre certains problèmes  financiers. Par conséquent elle sollicite un crédit de 100 000 frs destine a l’achat de niébé, spaghetti  pour renforcer son niveau d’activité  dans la vente de petit déjeuner. Car le moment le plus important de son activité c’est le matin, moment d’affluence et heure d’école. Ce crédit lui permettra de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle  et d’accroitre ses ressources pour mieux supporter la charge de ses enfants orphelins.
texts.en:
Mrs Bitty D. is a married woman aged 53 years. She lives in the Baye Laye area, specifically in the Wakhinane neighborhood. She is a member of the institution U-IMCEC (bank of Baye Laye) since April 2008. She has already benefitted from two loans. She is a widow who is responsible for nine children between the ages of 16 and 30 years old. Mrs D. is involved in the sale of breakfast foods in the morning. From time to time, she is also involved in the sale of female accessory items such as earrings and others. She has approximately 15 years of small business experience. Staying idle is not an option for her, which is the reason why she is interested in business which at least helps her address several economic problems. In consequence, she is asking for a 100,000 frs loan in order to purchase niébé (black eyed peas, in america) and spaghetti to support her sales of breakfast foods. At the moment, her the most important financial activity is undertaken in the morning, during busy times, as well as school hours. This allows her to satisfy the requests from her clients and improve her resources in order to better support the needs of her orphaned children.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Materials to reinforce her stock

loans.name: Ankadignongonyé Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes qui composent le groupe Ankadignongonyé sont toutes mariées avec en moyenne  36 ans, 6 enfants et  vivant toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux,  dans le village de Djoutièbougou relevant de la préfecture de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues par des relations de parenté, de mariage et de voisinage. 
C’est dans le souci de recherches de ressources financières complémentaires que ces femmes ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela pour faire le commerce de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles sont à leur  premier prêt de groupe, qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 200kg de noix de néré pour faire du Sounbala (très apprécié dans la sauce africaine), 300kg de feuilles de baobab séchées et 150kg de dah. 
Tous ces condiments sont achetés sur place dans le village de Djoutièbougou et environs, pour être revendus ensuite au comptant et en détail sur le marché de Bougouni à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent obtenir un bénéfice mensuel de 15.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé  dans les frais de santé de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
The women of Ankadignongonyé Group are all married. On average, they are 36 years old and have six children. They all live in extended traditional families with their brothers, sisters, cowives, children and husbands in the village of Djoutièbougou in the prefecture of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The group members know each other through family, marriage and neighborhood ties. On their search for additional income, they decided to join the credit program of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and become sellers of food condiments. This is their first group loan which they will use to buy 200 kilograms of néré nuts (the nuts are boiled and pounded to obtain a dark paste, which is made into various shapes (balls or ovals) and turned into sounbala, a highly appreciated ingredient for African sauces), 300 kilograms of dried baobab leaves (from monkey bread trees) and 150 kilograms of dah (hibiscus blossoms used to make drinks). The women will buy all these condiments in Djoutièbougou and other nearby villages, and retail them for cash at the market in Bougouni to a clientele made up mainly of women. Thanks to the loan, they expect to make an average monthly profit of 15,000 CFA francs, which they will spend on healthcare for their children.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food condiments

loans.name: C2352 Twisungane Group

texts.en:
T. Ester is 30 years old and is married with five children aged between 3 and 15. Her husband is driver and they both work hard for their family.

T. is the group leader of five members, all of whom have different businesses, mostly fruits and vegetables. T. owns a small shop which sells different kinds of products such as toothpaste, cosmetic products, juice and so on. She employs one person as a helper so that her business runs well. The hours of her shop are from seven in the morning to six in the evening, every day except Sunday. This her 3rd successful year in her business.

T. and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses through purchasing more products to sell. With this loan, T. and her group hope to increase their monthly profits which will allow them to sustain their businesses.

loans.use: To buy additional products for her shop

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en:
Yusuf is 44 years old and married with 4 children who attend school.  He has run a dairy farm for the past ten years.  Yusuf earns the majority of his income by selling milk to the Kenyan Cooperative of Cremeries.  He says that some challenges exist, mainly diseases and the high costs of animal feed.

Yusuf has a good credit history with Juhudi Kilimo.  He recently completed a loan of Kes. 45,000.  He now requests a loan for Kes. 80,000 to purchase a dairy cow.  The extra income will help him pay school fees for his children and cover his personal expenses. In the future, Yusuf would like to acquire additional pedigree cows which produce over 50 liters of milk per day.

loans.use: Buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Benk Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe BENK sont toutes mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et  3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux. Elles résident dans le village de Djoutièbougou de la préfecture de Bougouni, troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de parenté. 
Après avoir rencontré beaucoup de difficultés à acheter des condiments alimentaires au comptant avec leurs fournisseurs, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elles sont à leur neuvième prêt de groupe après avoir remboursés  les huit précédents prêts sans aucune difficulté. 
Avec ce prêt elles  comptent acheter, 150kg d’oignon, 250kg de sel de cuisine et 50 paquets de 100 morceaux de cube maggi. Tous ces condiments sont achetés dans le marché de Bougouni pour être revendus en détail, au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. Avec ce prêt les femmes espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 20.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour soutenir les frais de santé et d’éducation des enfants.
texts.en:
The women of Benk Group are all married. On average, they are 30 years old and have three children. They all live in extended traditional families with their brothers, sisters, cowives, children and husbands in the village of Djoutièbougou in the prefecture of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women know each other through family ties. Having met with many difficulties to buy food condiments for cash from their suppliers, they decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. This is their ninth group loan. They repaid their previous eight loans without any difficulty. The women will use their loan to buy 200 kilograms of onions, 250 kilograms of cooking salt and 50 packs of 100 bouillon cubes. They will buy all these condiments at the market of Bougouni and retail them for cash or credit to a clientele made up mainly of women. Thanks to the loan, they expect to make an average monthly profit of 20,000 CFA francs, which they will spend on healthcare and school fees for their children.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food condiments

loans.name: Léocadie

texts.fr: H. Léocadie est née le 09 Décembre 1952 à Parakou dans le Nord du Bénin. Léocadie vit depuis 43 ans au quartier Wologuèdè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Léocadie est mariée à ADOUKONOU Célestin et a des enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Léocadie vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte les différentes charges de la famille. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Léocadie vend des poissons frits, des condiments de sauce et de l'huile de palme et d'arachide à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Léocadie achète ses divers produits. Léocadie voudrait renforcer son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle, afin d'augmenter son chiffre d'affaire. C'est pour cette raison que Léocadie sollicite pour une première fois un crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Léocadie H. is born on December 9, 1952 in Parakou, in the north of Benin. She has been living for 43 years in the Wologuède district of Cotonou, the economic capital o Benin. Léocadie is married to Célestin Adoukonou and has children, all of whom go to school. Lóecadie lives together with her husband and children. The couple share responsibility for the family expenses. In order to provide for her family needs, Léocadie sells fried fish, food sauces, palm oil and peanut oil, from her home. She buys her stock in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Léocadie would like to boost her business and better respond to customer demand in order to increase her revenues. This is the reason she is seeking her first loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing palm oil, peanut oil and food sauces (for resale)

loans.name: Bowale

texts.en:
Bowale is 45 years old and married with four children. Her husband also works to support their home. Her children are excelling in their jobs and education and this gives her joy. 

To make a living in Ibadan, Oyo state, she sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She has a stall where she sells her groceries. Her customers are usually friends and residents. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. 

She is requesting a loan of 70,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi est composé de femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 27 ans et  3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles nucléaires avec leurs enfants et époux, dans la ville de Bougouni au quartier Massabla-coura, en troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de commerce. 
Pour  d’augmenter leur ressource financière afin de faire assez de stocks,  elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les cinq prêts précédents, elles sont à leur sixième  prêt de groupe. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt elles comptent acheter, 1tonne de haricot, 500kg de fonio et 800kg de petit mil auprès des fournisseurs des foires hebdomadaires de Sido, Bladiè  et Kologo pour  être  ensuite revendus en gros et au comptant aux grossistes du marché de Bougouni. Leur clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes espèrent obtenir un bénéfice mensuel de 40.000 FCFA qui sera réutilisé elles dans leur activité.
texts.en:
The women of Benkadi Group ("Harmony") are all married. On average, they are 27 years old and have three children. They live in nuclear families with their children and husbands in the neighborhood of Massabla-Coura in Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women know each other through business ties. To boost their working capital and have sufficient inventory, they decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. After having repaid their previous five loans on schedule, they apply now for their sixth group loan. The women will use their new loan to buy 1 ton of beans, 500 kilograms of fonio (the smallest of all species of millet) and 800 kilograms of small millet. They will buy their products at the weekly fairs in Sido, Bladiè and Kologo, and sell them for cash to wholesalers at the market in Bougouni. Their clientele is made up of men and women. Thanks to the loan, they expect to make a monthly profit of 40,000 CFA francs, which they will reinvest in their business.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Christine Jerop

texts.en:
Christine Jerop T., 41, is a single mother of three children.  She is a farmer who plants maize for resale in in Eldoret, Kenya.  Christine has been farming for ten years.  She also sell vegetables to her neighbors, who are her major clients.

Christine was introduced to KADET by an existing client and this will be her second loan. With the loan she plans to work on her farm and plant and harvest more maize for income.

Her goal is to become a better farmer, feed and educate her children and pay their medical bills.

loans.use: Plant and harvest maize.

loans.name: Diamadjigui Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Diamadjigui est composé de femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles nucléaires avec leurs enfants et époux dans le village de Djoutièbougou, préfecture de Bougouni, troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de commerce. 
Avec l’idée d’améliorer leur pouvoir d’achat, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela pour faire le commerce de céréales. 
Elles sont à leur neuvième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt elles comptent acheter, 2 tonnes de maïs et 1,5 tonnes de haricot. Les produits sont achetés auprès des fournisseurs du village de Djoutièbougou et  environs pour être revendus ensuite en détail, au comptant ou à crédit sur le marché Bougouni. Leur clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes espèrent obtenir un bénéfice mensuel de 25.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans l’entretien de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
The group Diamadjigui is composed of married women who average 32 years of age and four children each. The women live in nuclear families with their children and husbands in the village of Djoutièbougou, Prefecture of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women know one another through business relations. With the idea of improving their purchasing power, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to do business in grains and are now on their ninth group loan. The preceding loans have all been repaid. With this new loan, they intend to buy 2 tonnes of corn and 1½ tonnes of beans. The goods are purchased from supplies in and around the village of Djoutièbougou and are then sold at the Bougouni market. Cash and credit are accepted from their customer base composed of men and women. With this loan, the women hope to obtain a monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA that will be used to support their children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grains

loans.name: Pascaline

texts.fr: Née en Avril 1961 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, T. Pascaline vit depuis 29 ans au quartier Sètovi à Cotonou. Pascaline est mariée à WOLI Jean-Baptiste un commerçant, et est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais seulement deux des enfants restent encore à la charge du couple. Pascaline vient en aide à son mari et contribue aux charges familiales. N'ayant jamais fréquenté l'école, Pascaline a commencé il y a sept ans environs, la vente de divers produits (riz, maïs, huile d'arachide, épices, etc.) dans son quartier. Pascaline se ravitaille à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Pascaline a obtenu une fois déjà un prêt de ALIDé, et l'a bien remboursé. Pascaline sollicite à nouveau un autre crédit afin d'augmenter le stock de ses produits et de mieux répondre aux multiples exigences de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in April 1961 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Ms. T. Pascaline has been living for 29 years in the Sètovi district in Cotonou. She is married to Mr. WOLI Jean-Baptiste, a merchant, and is the mother of four children, who have all attended school. But only two of the children still remain in the couple's care. Pascaline helps out her husband and takes part in covering family expenses. Never having attended school, Pascaline began selling a diversity of goods about seven years ago. She sells rice, corn, peanut oil, spices, etc. in her district. She stocks up from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She once obtained an ALIDé loan already and has repaid it. Pascaline is again requesting another loan in order to increase her inventory and to respond better to the multiple requirements of her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying containers of oil and sacks of corn and rice

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard is 30 years old, married and the father of two school age children.  He operates a motorcycle transport business in Naivasha and ferries people and goods around town.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan.  He paid his first loan of Kshs 10,000 well, which he used to repair his motorbike.  He plans to buy a new motorbike with this second loan.  He will employ somebody to operate it for him.  This will significantly increase his daily income.

He loves the transportation business and plans to own a fleet of taxis and motorbikes.

loans.use: Buy a new motorbike.

loans.name: C2141 Twuzuzanye Group

texts.en:
Fortune is 44 years old and is married with two children, 15 and 18 years old. She also takes care of one dependent who is not a relative. Her husband does not work.

Fortune works hard for her family. She is also the group representative of this group called Twuzuzanye in the local language. This group contains six members; most of them sell green bananas although one sells vegetables.

Fortune and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing their businesses. Each of them has a target of increasing their business through purchasing more various products for sale. Fortune and her group have businesses that are known in the market where their businesses are located.

Fortune has been in her operation of selling vegetables for four years. Her business is open two days a week on Wednesdays and Fridays; the hours of her business are from seven in the morning to eight in the evening.

With this loan, Fortune and her group expect to earn more profits which will allow them to save money for the future.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Ann Njeri

texts.en:
Ann is 32 years old and married. She sells clothes at the Westlands market in Nairobi. This market is busy and Ann has customers regularly. This has been her primary business for the last three years now.
Ann was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by an existing member. This is her first loan with KADET and she has not borrowed from other financial institutions. With this loan, she hopes to buy more stock of new clothes and grow her business substantially.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to add to her stock

loans.name: Adebola

texts.en: Adebola is 45 years old and married with four children. Her husband also works to support their home. Her children are excelling in school, and this gives her joy. She is a friendly and hardworking woman. To make a living in Ibadan, Oyo State, she sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She has a stall where she sells her groceries. Her customers are usually friends and residents. In the future, she hopes to own a supermarket. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 70,000 NGN in order to purchase more groceries to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Faïda Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Faïda est composé de femmes mariées ayant en moyenne 32 ans, 3 enfants et vivant dans des familles  traditionnelles, avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux, dans le village de Djoutièbougou, préfecture de Bougouni, troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de voisinage et de parenté. 
Pour mener à bien leurs activités commerciales, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela pour faire le commerce de céréales. 
Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter auprès des fournisseurs de Djoutièbougou et environs, 1tonne de petit mil, 400 kg de fonio et 600 kg maïs. Ces produits sont revendus aux grossistes en détail et au comptant dans le marché de Bougouni, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt elles espèrent  obtenir  un bénéfice mensuel de 20.000 FCFA qui sera réutilisé dans leurs activités.
texts.en:
The group Faïda is composed of married women averaging 32 years of age and three children each living in traditional families, with their brothers, sisters, co-wives, children, and husband, in the village of Djoutièbougou, Prefecture of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know one another by ties of community and kinship. To carry out their commercial activities, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to do business in grains. The women are on their fourth group loan. The previous loans have all been properly repaid. With this loan, they intend to buy from suppliers in and around Djoutièbougou the following: a tonne of pearl millet, 400 kg of fonio (a local grain), and 600 kg of corn. These goods are sold to wholesalers. Cash or credit is accepted from a customer base composed of men and women at the Bougouni market. With this loan, the group members hope to obtain a monthly profit of 20,000 francs CFA that will be re-used in their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grains

loans.name: Laïdou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Laïdou est composé de femmes mariées ayant  une moyenne d’âge de 26 ans, 2 enfants et vivant dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux dans le village de Djoutièbougou préfecture de Bougouni, troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de mariage et de commerce. 
Dans l’intention d’augmenter leurs ressources financières, elles décident d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela pour faire le commerce de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt de groupe qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 7 boites de 2kg de  concentrée de tomate, 4 sacs de 25kg de sel de cuisine, 10 paquets de 100 morceaux de cube maggi et diverses autres qualités de condiments. Les produits sont payés auprès des grossistes de Bougouni pour ensuite être revendus en détail, au comptant ou à crédit dans le village de Djoutièbougou à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt, ces femmes du groupe Laïdou  comptent obtenir un bénéfice mensuel de 25.000FCFA  qui sera utilisé  dans les frais de santé et d’éducation de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
The Laïdou group is made up of married women with the average age of 26, 2 children and live in traditional polygamous extended families with their brothers, sisters, children and husbands in the town of Djoutièbougou in the third administrative district of Mali, Bougouni. These women know each other via family and business relationship. With the intention of increasing their financial resources they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution so they can be in the business of selling food goods. They are asking for their first group loan, to be used for the purchase of 7 boxes of 2 kg canned puree, 4 25 kg bags of kitchen salt, 10 packs of 100 count bouillon cubes and a variety of types of condiments. The products are paid for wholesale in Bougouni to be sold retail in town of Djoutièbougou. They accept both cash and credit from a client base primarily made up of women. WIth the loan, the women of the Laïdou group count on gaining a monthly income of 25.000 FCFA which will be used to pay for the health and educational expenses of their children.

Translated from French by Colleen Creegan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of edible condiments

loans.name: Fati

texts.fr: A. A. Fati est née le 05 Janvier 1974 et vit depuis une dizaine d'année au quartier Wologuèdè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Fati est mariée à EGOUWOLLE Falilou et a des enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Wologuèdè et le couple assure les différentes charges. Fati a été à l'école jusqu'au cours secondaire. Après son mariage, Fati à commencé la vente de charbon de bois et mène cette activité à son domicile. A côté de cette activité, Fati vend également du maïs. Fati s'approvisionne à l'intérieur du pays. C'est la première fois que Fati sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un crédit, en vue d'augmenter le stock de ses produits et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. Ainsi, Fati pourra également se faire plus de revenu et développer un peu plus son activité.
texts.en:
Fati A. A. was born on Jan 5th, 1974 and for the past decade has lived in the Wologuèdè neighborhood in Cotonou, the economic capitol of Bénin. Fati is married to Falilou Egouwolle and has children that she sends to school. The family lives together in Wologuèdè and the pair takes care of the different responsibilities. Fati was in school up until high school. After her marriage, Fati started selling charcoal from her home. In addition, Fati also sells corn. Fati gets her supplies in the interior of her country. This is the first time that Fati is asking ALIDé for a loan, in the hopes of increasing the stocks of her products and to better meet the needs of her customers. Thus, Fati will be able to equally make more of an income and grow her business.

Translated from French by Colleen Creegan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal

loans.name: Tikise

texts.en:
Tikise K. is a 44-year-old married man with three children. He has a cattle farming business, buying livestock for fattening and reselling them in Rongai market. He has been in this business for the last ten years, and makes a monthly profit of approximately 40,000 KES.
Tikise has never borrowed from another micro-finance institution (MFI). He wants to use his loan to buy more cows and goats for fattening. He hopes to increase the number of his livestock in order to earn more profit.

loans.use: To purchase cows and goats for fattening

loans.name: Ngeno

texts.en:
Ngeno is 26-year-old single man with no children. He has been running a dairy farm near the town of Litein in western Kenya for the past two years. His primary income comes from selling milk to Brookside, a dairy company in Kenya, but he also earns income from tea farming and poultry. Ngeno says that the main challenge he faces now is constraints on available capital for his farming.
Ngeno recently completed his first loan with Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, for 20,000 KES. He has now requested a new loan of 50,000 KES to purchase a motorbike. He says that the extra income from this loan will help improve his net worth and aid in his farming practices.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Ventina

texts.en: This is 30-year-old Mrs. N. Ventina. For over two years, she has run a beauty salon where she sells hair chemicals, hair shampoo, hair gel, sprays, powders, beads and so forth. She is requesting a loan to stock hair accessories such as hair chemicals, hair shampoo, hair gel, sprays, powders, beads and so forth for sale in her beauty salon business. Ventina is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase hair chemicals, hair shampoo, hair gel, sprays, powders, beads etc.

loans.name: Risik

texts.en:
Risik is 54 years old, and she is still very energetic. She is a widow who lost her husband some years ago. She sells groceries, foodstuffs, and drinks in her shop. She loves her business, because it gives her the opportunity to take care of herself, as well as her two children's financial needs. She has been in the business for the past 25 years, and she has been able to use her years of experience to retain her customers.

She hopes to expand her business more, and she hopes for this loan of 100,000 NGN in order to purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell. She expresses her gratitude to Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Oussama

texts.en:
Oussama is a 38-year-old single woman who lives with her parents and three sisters. In 2000, she opened a small mini-market in her town, where she offers food products, soft drinks, bread, chocolates, and other items. She cooperates, along with her sisters, to provide income and satisfy the demands of life. Her mini-market is situated in a busy area. She has been able, over the years, to have a growing number of clients passing by her shop and buying all types of food products. She has taken a first loan from Kiva, and she said that it has impacted her work positively.

Today, Oussama is asking for a second loan of 1,200 USD to buy more products in order to increase her sales.

loans.use: To buy more products

loans.name: Radha

texts.en: Mrs. Radha C. is a grocery store keeper in the town of Tangal. She opened her grocery store to improve her family's economic conditions. She sells a variety of grocery goods in her shop, such as rice, maize, biscuits, noodles, snacks, etc. Nowadays in her area, the demand for grocery goods is increasing. Therefore, to meet customer demand Mrs. Radha C. is requesting a loan of 30,000 NPR to buy various types of grocery goods. She spends her income in fulfilling the needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy grocery good s

loans.name: Rajika

texts.en:
Rajika is a 30-year-old married woman living with her two children in the town of Dickwella, Sri Lanka. Her husband is working abroad so Rajika must provide local family support for her children.

Rajika has a tailoring business that she has been running for three years now. She is a very hard worker and an honest woman, which has helped her to expand her business to where it is currently. However, she has plans to improve it for the future and needs some additional capital to do so.

Rajika is seeking a 40,000 LKR loan from BRAC. This is actually her second loan for her tailoring business as her first loan of 20,000 LKR was successfully repaid. Ultimately she hopes to expand enough to be able to provide employment for one or two people in the community.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy more cloth for her tailoring business

loans.name: Richard Kimaiyo

texts.en:
Richard Kimaiyo K. is a thirty-six year old man married to Monica Tanui and they are blessed with six lovely children. He lives in Sergoit in Eldoret and he is a maize farmer in the same area. He has been farming for the last twelve years and besides farming he also sells milk to one of Kenya’s biggest milk suppliers, the Kenya Cooperative Creameries. 

He came to know about KADET through his friends where he stays.  This will be his first loan from KADET and he plans to use the entire loan for maize farming through things like hiring a tractor for digging, buying maize seedlings and fertilizers.

Richard's life goals are to continue farming and become a better farmer, buy land on which to build rental houses, and educate his children to the highest level.

loans.use: To use in maize farming

loans.name: Tunde

texts.en: Tunde sells building materials at retail prices to his customers. He has been in this business for a long time, and he uses his experience in business to attract and retain more customers. He hopes to expand his business. He is 37 years old and married with three children. His wife has a beauty salon, and she also supports her husband in meeting the basic needs of their family. He is requesting a loan in the amount of 80,000 NGN in order to purchase more building materials to sell. He thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: C2142 Umuhoza Group

texts.en:
Liberathe is 52 years old and is married with four children aged between 16 and 24. She also takes care of one dependent. Her husband is a farmer and they both work hard to earn more revenue, even if in their agriculture activities they do not have enough income for their family.

Liberathe is the group representative of a group which is called Umuhoza in the local language. This group contains six members, most of whom sell green bananas.

Liberatha and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses through purchasing more products to sell. With this loan Liberathe and her group will be able to improve their family situations through providing all the basic needs of their families.

loans.use: To purchase more green bananas to sell

loans.name: Nanda Kumari

texts.en:
Mrs. Nanda Kumari N. is a 40 year old lady who lives in Dolchoki Village. Dolchoki Village is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in vegetable farming.

Mrs. Nanda Kumari lives with her husband and three children. She has two sons and one daughter. Her older son is studying in grade 3 and her younger son is studying in grade 1.  Her daughter is in grade 4.

Both husband and wife are engaged in vegetable farming. They own a piece of land where they grow green vegetables. They mostly grow seasonal vegetables on their land. They sell their vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening daily.

Now Mrs. Nanda Kumari is requesting her first loan of 10,000 NPR to buys seeds and fertilizers for their vegetable farming.

loans.use: To buys seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Bendiya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Bendiya est composé de femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et  4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles nucléaires avec leurs enfants et époux et résident dans le village de Sido, dans la préfecture de Bougouni,  troisième  région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces  femmes se sont connues par des relations de commerce. 
Dans l’intention d’augmenter leur ressource financière et de faire assez de stocks enfin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela pour faire le commerce des condiments alimentaires. 
Elles sont à leur dixième prêt de groupe et  tous les neuf  précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter, 50 boites de 2kg de concentrée de tomate, 20 sacs de 25kg de sel de cuisine, 30 paquets de 100 morceaux de cube maggi, 100kg d’arachide qui sera transformé en pâte d’arachide et diverses autres qualités de condiments. Une partie des produits seront achetée auprès des grossistes de Bamako et l’autre partie sera achetée localement dans le village de Sido. Elles effectuent leurs ventes dans le grand marché de Sido à  une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes, en détail au comptant ou à crédit. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes comptent obtenir un bénéfice de 30.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé dans leur activité.
texts.en:
The Bendiya group is made up of married women with an average age of 32 and 4 children. They live in nuclear families with their husband and children in the town of Sido in the 3 administrative district of Mali, Bougouni. These women know each other through family and business relationships. With the intention of increasing their financial resources and to have enough back-stock to meet their clients needs, they have decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution. Their business is selling food goods. They are on their 10th group loan. The previous nine were properly repaid. With this loan they count on buying 50 boxes of 2 kg tomato puree, 20 twenty five kg bags of kitchen salt, 30 packs of 100 count bouillon cubes, 100 kg of peanuts, they will make into peanut butter and a variety of other condiments. A portion of the product will be purchased wholesale in Bamako and the rest will be purchased locally in the town of Sido. They will conduct their sales at the main market in Sido to a clientele of primarily women, paid for in cash or with credit. WIth the loan the women count on earning a profit of 30.000 FCFA per month that will be used for their business.

Translated from French by Colleen Creegan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of food condiments

loans.name: Gideon

texts.en:
Gideon is 22 years old and for the last three years he has been employed as a motorbike rider to transport people and goods around Naivsaha town.  

While on this job he has learned the benefits of the occupation and he wants to operate his own motorbike. With this in mind, he started looking for a financier and that’s when a friend introduced him to KADET.  This will be his first loan, which he will use to buy his own motorbike and create his own employment.

He plans to save the profits from his motorbike operations, which he will use to open up a wholesale shop in Naivasha town dealing with basic home commodities.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Inoka

texts.en:
Inoka is a 35-year-old married woman living in the town of Dickwella, Sri Lanka. She and her husband have no children but they help to support Inoka's mother. Inoka’s husband works in a government job, while Inoka has a plastic goods shop.

Inoka’s mother has worked with Inoka for many years to prepare short eats, which are quick meals they produce and sell. But now Inoka has started a new business: a plastic-goods shop. Because of the low competition in the area, she has seen initial success and hopes to further expand.

Inoka is seeking a 40,000 LKR loan from BRAC to help expand her business as currently she does not have the financial capital necessary to grow.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy plastic goods for her shop

loans.name: Julienne

texts.fr: Née en 1962, T. Julienne vit depuis 12 ans environs au quartier Sètovi à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Julienne est mariée à SAGBO Jean-Paul un militaire, et a cinq enfants à sa charge. Tous les cinq enfants sont scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble et le couple assure les différentes charges familiales. Julienne a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Julienne prépare et vend de la nourriture (pâte de maïs et de cossette d'igname) dans son quartier. De façon secondaire, Julienne vend également des chaussures. Julienne se ravitaille à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomé au Togo. Julienne avait obtenu deux prêts de ALIDé, et les a tous bien remboursés. La clientèle de Julienne s'accroît au jour le jour et elle n'arrive plus à tous les satisfaire. C'est donc pour renforcer son capital et augmenter sa production journalière que Julienne sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième prêt.
texts.en:
Born in 1962, Julienne T. has lived for around 12 years in the Sètovi district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Julienne is married to Jean-Paul SAGBO, a military, and has five children in her care. All five children attend school. The family lives together and the couple covers the various family expenses. Julienne left school during secondary level. To provide for her needs and those of her children, she prepares and sells food (corn pasta and "cossette", a type of cereal made from yams) in her neighborhood. As a secondary activity Julienne also sells shoes. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market, and in Lomé in Togo. Julienne has had two loans from ALIDé and has repaid them both without incident. Her customer base is growing from day to day and she cannot satisfy them all. In order to strengthen her capital and increase her daily producttion she is thus applying for a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat de sacs de maïs et de cossettes d'igname. Purchase of bags of corn and yam "cossettes".

loans.name: Josphine

texts.en: Josphine is 29 years old, and married with three children who go to school. For the past three years, she has been running a shop where she sells cereals and has plans to grow her business. Her husband works in a factory. Since she became a member of Faulu Kenya, her business has grown because she can access loans. She aims to improve her business and establish a strong reputation in her neighborhood. Her dream is to someday grow her business into a wholesale enterprise. She has requested for a loan of kes. 60,000 to buy more cereals for sale.

loans.use: To add stock of cereals for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more firewood to sell

loans.name: Aminat

texts.en: Aminat sells colorful sarongs at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. Sarongs are worn mostly by women and young ladies in Nigeria. She has been in this business for 10 years. She is 35 years old and married with two children. Her husband sells motor spare parts. She is requesting a loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel is 28 years old and married. He has been selling milk for three years in Nairobi. He also farms to increase his earnings. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, his business has really grown because he can access loans. He hopes to open outlets and improve his standard of living in the future. He has requested a loan of kes 70,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy a cooker to boil milk.

loans.use: To buy a cooker to boil milk

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 22 years old. He and his wife Mary Wangari, have a nine-month-old baby. In 2007 he was employed as a motorbike rider to transport people and goods around Naivsaha town but he later decided to buy his own motorbike.  

John was introduced to KADET by his friend. This will be his first loan. He plans to save the profis from the sale of his old motorbike and the funding from KADET buy more motorbikes and employ people to run them for him. He anticipates this will secure his income base.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Ramala

texts.en:
Mrs. Ramala N. is a resident of Dolchoki Village. Dolchoki is located in Lalitpur district. It is one of the developing village of Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in agriculture. Mrs. Ramala has six members including herself in her family. She lives with her husband and four children. She has three sons and one daughter. Her sons are studying in grade 9, 5 and 3, respectively, and daughter is studying in grade 7.
Both Mrs. N. and Mr. N. are engaged in vegetable farming. They own a piece of land and they grow green vegetables. They grow seasonal vegetables on their land due to the lack of modern tools and technology. They sell their vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening daily. Now Mrs. N. is a loan of for Rs 10000 to buy seeds and fertilizer for their vegetable farm.

loans.use: To buys seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Irene

texts.en: Irene is 23 years old and married with two children. She runs a retail shop where she sells general merchandise such as sugar, cooking fat, salt, rice, vegetables and cereals.  Her business is located in south B, an estate in the southern part of the capital city, Nairobi. She has been involved in this business for two years and she has three employees. She also rents out her residential houses to increase her earnings.  She had previously taken out a loan of Kes 50,000, which she used to expand her business and successfully repaid. She hopes to grow her business into a wholesale one and improve her living standards in the future. She has requested a loan of Kes 75,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy a weighing machine (scale) and cereals.

loans.use: To buy a weighing machine and cereals

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 37-year-old single mother of three school-going children. She has been selling charcoal in Naivasha town for the last five years.

Margaret was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her second loan.  She used the first loan of Kshs 10,000 to buy charcoal for resale and she paid it back well.  Demand for charcoal has increased steadily and she is seeking more funding from KADET to buy more sacks of charcoal for sale. 

She plans to open a retail shop and operate it as a second source of income in the near future.

loans.use: To buy five sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: C2349 Umoja Group

texts.en:
Francine is 36 years old and is married with five children aged between 3 and 13 years. Her husband works as a businessman; they both work hard for their family.
