Francine is the leader of this group which is called Umoja in the Swahili language; this group contains five members and all of them own the small shop which sells various products. Francine has an experience of two years in her business of selling rice, salt, bananas, juice, soda, and a traditional soft drink made from sorghum which called ubushera in the local language. 

Francine and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing their business which will allow them to get ahead. With this loan Francine hopes to change her family situation through providing all the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en:
Solomon is 44 years old, married to Fresia Wambui, and they have four children who attend school. He has operated a general store in Naivasha town for the last five years.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan. He used the first loan of Kshs 50,000 to buy more stock for his shop and has paid the loan. He now plans to add more dry food stuff — bags of rice, sugar, and maize flour which he will sell to his clients in small quantities. The shop is profitable, and to make it even more so he plans to add a variety of  new products — especially products demanded by his customers.

loans.use: To buy dry food stuff to restock his shop

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert is a hard-working man who lives with his wife and two children who attend school. He has been running a butcher's shop for four years in the Mlolongo area in Nairobi. He has four employees who assist him in the business. His wife, who is a business lady, helps with the household expenses. He had previously requested for a loan of kes 40,000 from Faulu Kenya which he used to expand his business and has successfully repaid. He hopes to grow his business in the future and has requested a loan of kes 60,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy more goats and a weighing scale.

loans.use: To buy goats and a weighing scale

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 44 years of age and she is married with seven children. She sells fairly used bags and she has been in the business for over a year. With her last Kiva loan, she changed her line of business. She started selling fairly used bags and she stopped selling drinks, which was her initial trade. 

Helen is very happy with her present business because it gives her more profit, more time to look after her children and to attend church fellowship. 
She hopes for a loan of NGN 120,000 to purchase more fairly used bags to sell. Helen appreciates all Kiva lenders for the wonderful initiative.

loans.use: To purchase more fairly used bags to sell.

loans.name: Amos

texts.en:
Amos is 38 years old, married to Jeniffer Wanjiru, with two children who go to school. Since 2005, he has been in the motorcycle transport business ferrying  people and goods from one place to another.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to renew his PSV (Public Service Vehicle) license and buy a helmet for his passengers. He hopes to grow his business and even in the future to buy a mini van.

loans.use: To buy a passenger helmet and renew his PSV license

loans.name: Kafayat

texts.en: Kafayat is 38 years old and married with four children. Her husband also works to support their home. Her children are excelling in their school and this gives her joy. She is a friendly and hard working woman. To make a living in Ibadan, Oyo state, she sells electrical materials at retail prices to her customers. She has a stall where she sells her electrical materials. Her customers are usually friends and residents. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more electrical materials to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electrical materials to sell

loans.name: Noeline

texts.en: Mrs. N. Noeline is thirty-five years old, and she has a party business. She is using the loan to purchase papers, cards, decorations, frames, earrings, and so forth, for sale. She has been operating her business for a period of four years. She wants to be a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: To purchase papers, cards, decorations, frames, earrings, and so forth for sale.

loans.name: Juna

texts.en:
Mrs. Juna N. lives in Dolchoki Village. She lives with her husband and two children. She has one son and one daughter. Her son is studying in grade 1 and daughter is studying in grade 3.

Both Mrs. N. and her husband Mr. Lekba N. are farmer in the village of Dolchoki. They owns a piece of land where they grow seasonal vegetables. They sell their vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening daily. Mrs. Magarkoti is requesting the first loan to buy seeds and fertilizer for their vegetable farming.

loans.use: to buys seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Asma

texts.en:
Asma runs a small shop in Rafah city in Gaza Strip. Raghad, Lamees and Yaser are her three children. Her husband Arafat, who appears in her shop in the picture above, is an employee of the Palestinian Authority with a decent salary.  Asma decided to start her shop to help the family cover their expenses.

In order to fill the shop with goods Asma took a loan from FATEN.  Since then the number of customers has increased and returns are improving.

Asma comes from a conservative background and doesn't accept having her picture published.

loans.use: To buy more goods to fill the supermarket

loans.name: Salman

texts.en:
Salman is a 30-year-old married man and father of two school-age children. He has owned a watch and gadgets shop for the past 10 years in his town. He sells and repairs watches and he has prepared a special corner for selling gadgets. He works hard because he is the only provider for his family and his only purpose is to get his children university degrees. 

Today, Salman is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy a variety of gadgets and watches to attract more clients to his shop. Salman hopes that his diverse selection of items will continue to generate good profits and enable him to expand his business even further. He expects his productivity and income to increase in the coming year.

loans.use: To buy a variety of gadgets and watches

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is 42 years old and married with three children who go to school. He has been selling timber for twenty years to earn a living. He also practices farming for commercial purposes to get enough money to support his family and to pay school fees for his children. He appreciates Faulu Kenya for the training they offered him on business management, for he has become focused and his business has grown. He hopes to expand his business and increase his turnover in the future. He has requested for a loan from Faulu Kenya to buy more timber for selling.

loans.use: To buy more timber to sell

loans.name: Manku

texts.en:
Mrs. Manku N. is the resident of Dolchoki Village. Dolchoki is located in Ialitpur district. Dolchoki is one of the underdeveloped villages of lalitpur, and most of the people in this region are engaged in agriculture. Mrs. N. lives with her husband and two sons. Her older son is studying in grade 3 and the younger son is studying in grade 2.

Both Mrs. N. and Mr. N. are farmers in the village of Dolchoki. They grows seasonal vegetable in their land. They sell their vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening daily. Now Mrs. N. is requesting for a loan to buys seeds and fertilizer for their agricultural farming.

loans.use: to buys seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Hope

texts.en:
Hope sells drugs, drinks and groceries in her shop located in front of her house. She also works as a nurse in one of the clinics in Lagos state, Nigeria. She used her last Kiva loan to stock her shop with more drugs and groceries. This attracted more customers to her shop, made more sales and increased her profit. 

She is married with four children. She is 42 years old. Her husband is a businessman. He clears and forwards goods at the port. He works hard to sustain his immediate family needs. She hopes for a loan of NGN 170,000 to purchase more drugs, groceries and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for choosing her as a borrower.

loans.use: To purchase more drugs, groceries and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Pabitra

texts.en: Mrs. Pabitra G. is a farmer in the village of Dolchoki. She and her husband Mr. Tika Prasad G. grow green vegetables in their land. Mostly they grow seasonal vegetables in their land, and they sell their vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening daily. Now Mrs. Pabitra is requesting a loan to buys seeds and fertilizer for vegetable farming. They have one son who attends higher secondary school.

loans.use: to buys seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase kitchen hot and cold taps, sinks and toilet bowls to resell

loans.name: David

texts.en: David is 27 years old and married with one child. He sells clothes on a busy highway. He sells a variety of clothes such as men and womens' clothes. He has been involved in this business for three years. He has grown his business into a higher level and attributes his success to his strong marketing and communication skills. He is also employed as a driver, and with his earnings he is able to support his family. He dreams of growing his business into a wholesale operation and wants to improve his living standards in the future.  He has requested for a loan from Faulu Kenya to buy more clothes for selling.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for selling

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Juan

texts.es: El Señor Juan esta casado, vive en el municipio de la Guardia (La Guardia Por encontrarse cerca de la ciudad capital, cuenta con industrias, centros recreativos y urbanizaciones. Una de las más destacadas industrias y de importancia nacional e internacional es la Cervecería Boliviana Nacional, ubicada en este municipio, así como la fábrica de aceite Crisol. La cerveza, además de abastecer el mercado interno y ciudades aledañas, se exporta a diversos países de Sudamérica y Europa. )El Sr. Juan vive con su esposa y sus hijos, el señor trabaja con su vehiculo en el sector trasporte publico de pasajeros. El Señor Juan tiene el deseo de superarse economicamente junto con su esposa y sacar adelante a sus hijos y poder asi mejorar la calidad de vida de vida e toda su familia, con el dinero del credito realizara el mantenimiento de su vehiculo ya que tiene algunas fallas y no le permite brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes, el esta agradecido con la institucion por la oportunidad brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Mr. Juan is married and lives in the town of La Guardia. La Guardia, being close to the capital city, has industries, recreational centers and housing developments. One of the most relevant industrial plants, domestically and internationally, is the National Bolivian Brewery, which is located in the town, as well as the Crisol cooking oil plant. The Brewery, besides selling in the internal market and border towns, exports to many countries in South America and Europe. Mr. Juan lives with his wife and children. He works as a cab driver. He wants to improve his and his wife's financial conditions, provide for his children and improve the quality of life for him and his family. With the money from the loan he plans to perform maintenance in this vehicle since it has a few problems and doesn't allow him to provide a better service for his customers. He is thankful to the institution for the opportunity he has been given with the granting of the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle Maintenance

loans.name: C2351 Twiyubake Group

texts.en:
Jaqueline was born in 1980 and is married with four children aged between 3 and 11. Her husband is Macon.

Jaqueline is the group representative of five members. In this group, most of them sell fruits and vegetables. Jaqueline owns a restaurant which is well-known in the region.

Jaqueline and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses.  Jaqueline plans to purchase more foodstuffs to cook in her restaurant.

With this loan, Jaqueline and her group believe they will earn more profits which will help them to sort out some problems in their businesses as well as support their families.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for her restaurant

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas is 34 years old and is married with four children aged between 2 and 9 years. Her husband is an agriculture manager and they both work hard for their family.

Dorcas owns a small shop which sells different kinds of products such as rice, salt, sugar and another foodstuffs which are needed in her village. Her business is well-known and is profitable. The hours of her business are from six in the morning to seven in the evening, every day except Sunday.

Dorcas is seasoned in this business, the reason why is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing new foodstuffs to sell. With this loan, Dorcas will be able to be sustainable in her business which, in turn, will help her to save money for her future.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Titi

texts.en:
Titi sells and supplies building materials like blocks, sand, granite and cement. She is very popular and friendly in her community and she has been able to use this to attract and retain more customers. Titi has been in this business for the past 11 years. Her husband is a Nigerian police officer and they are blessed with three children. 

42-year-old Titi wants great improvement in her business and hopes for a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more building materials like sand, granite and cement to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for the financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials like sand, granite and cement to sell.

loans.name: Santa Kumari

texts.en:
Mrs. Santa Kumari N. is a farmer in the village of Dolchoki. She owns a piece of land where she grows green vegetables. Mostly she grows seasonal vegetables in her land, and she sells her vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening daily. She uses her income in fulfilling the needs of her family. Now Mrs. N. is requesting a loan to buys seeds and fertilizers for her farming. 

Mrs. N. lives with her husband and four children. Her husband Mr. Ram Bahadur N. is a carpenter. She has three sons and one daughter. Her sons are studying in grade 12, 10 and 8, respectively, and her daughter is in grade 5.

loans.use: to buys seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Salomon 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Sonia is the coordinator of her group, Solomon, and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti). Her group is located in the Samana Peninsula, a lush, rugged area with a nascent tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their three children.

Sonia is excited to be taking her eighth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business, selling underwear, by traveling to the capital and purchasing underwear in the main markets as well as a sewing machine. She will use the profits to invest in school supplies, medicine and clothes for her children. She also plans to save towards renting a location for her store, which she would like to eventually convert into a travel agency. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Underwear to sell, and a sewing machine

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 25-year-old single man who lives with his parents. After getting his university degree in pharmacy, he opened his own pharmacy, in 2009, after seeing a need for such services in the region. He's very happy with his business, because he's able to help his village clients.

Today, Ali is requesting to borrow 1,000 USD to build a tent beside the pharmacy in order to make more space and to expand his business even further.

loans.use: To build a tent

loans.name: Salam

texts.en:
Salam is a 32-year-old man who is married and lives in Rafah city in Gaza Strip. Salam is a National Palestinian Authority employee and owns a computer selling and maintenance store which is considered to be his main source of income.

Salam requested a loan from FATEN to purchase more computers which will increase his number of customers, whether for buying or coming back for maintenance. Islam has a good number of customers and covers a large area of his city.

Salam is the one behind the desk in the picture above.

loans.use: Purchasing more computers

loans.name: Shaheen's Group

texts.en:
Shaheen is 38-year old lady married and a citizen of a city named Borewala, Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. 
Her husband name is M. A. who has animal selling business. He has been in this profession for the back 25 years. He has knowledge of every breed of animals but he sells specifically (goats and sheep).  His mostly clients are butchers because they demand him about the animals and he completes their orders. 
Shaheen is applying for a loan to buy animals (goats & sheep) to expand her husbands’ animal selling business.

loans.use: To buy animals for her animal selling business

loans.name: C2894 Duteraninkunga Group

texts.en:
Assoumpta is 38 and is married with two children; the firstborn is 14 years old and the youngest is four years old. Her husband works in a transport association and both work hard for their family.

Assoumpta is the group representative of this group which is called Duteraninkunga in the local language. This group contains five members and each of them has a different business.

Assoumpta has an experience of one year in her clothing business. The hours of her business are from six in the morning to six in the evening, every day except Sunday.

Assoumpta and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to improve their business situations. With this loan Assoumpta and her group hope to earn more monthly profits through purchasing more products which will allow them to attract new customers.

loans.use: To buy a variety of styles of clothes to sell

loans.name: Rashda's Group

texts.en: Rashda, the wife of M. A., lives in a city famous for its shrines named Borewala, Pakistan.  Rashda, who is uneducated because her parents couldn’t afford her education expenses, spends her time taking care of her family and doing household work. Her husband is a mechanic employed in a motor workshop where he repairs all type of vehicles from bicycles to cars.  He is an expert in his work but unfortunately hasn't been able to start his own workshop due to a lack of capital. Therefore Rashda has decided to apply for a loan so that her husband can open his own workshop by purchasing the necessary repair tools.

loans.use: To buy tools necessary to start a motor workshop

loans.name: Johanah

texts.en: Johanah is 38 years old and married with four children. Two of the children are in school. He has been running a laundry shop together with his wife for eight years to earn a living. He also practices farming to increase his income to support his family and pay school fees for his children. He had previously taken out a loan from Faulu Kenya which he used to expand his business. He has requested for another loan to buy laundry materials.

loans.use: To buy laundry materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Las Vecinas 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Calixta is the coordinator of her group Las Vecinas (The Neighbors), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti). Her group is located in the Samana PeninsuL., a rush, lugged area with a nascent tourism industry where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their three children.

Calixta is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling jewelry and clothing by purchasing more of these goods, and she additionally plans to purchase a machine to grind coconut meat so that she can sell coconut candies. She will use the profits to invest in clothing, school supplies and a computer for her children. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Jewelry and clothes to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace sells foodstuffs like semovita, as well as other groceries and drinks in her shop. She has been in this business for the past two years. She appreciates her business, because she makes a profit, which she can use to support her husband in taking care of the family.

Grace is 37 years old and married with three children. Her children are doing well in school. She hopes for the loan of 170,000 NGN in order to purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell. Grace has been a member in LAPO microfinance with a good record. She thanks Kiva and LAPO for their initiatives.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria pertenece al banco comunal “Reyna de los Ángeles”, es natural de Urubamba, tiene 49 años, tiene cuatro hijos (Marlene, Edgar, Laura y Daniela), ella es una madre responsable que busca a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos.

Victoria se dedica a la venta de verduras, ella nos cuenta que los días lunes,  miércoles y sábados viaja a la ciudad del Cusco llevando sus productos para venderlos en el mercado de Huancaro. Ya son 30 años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su negocio. Victoria requiere el préstamo para comprar semillas como por ejemplo de flor, repollo, lechuga, sapallo, etc.      

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Victoria belongs to the Reyna de los Ángeles Communal Bank. She is a native of Urubamba. She is 49, and she has four children (Marlene, Edgar, Laura, and Daniela). She is a responsible mother who is every moment looking for opportunities to get ahead. She looks to give her children a better future through her daily effort. Victoria sells vegetables. She sells on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Saturdays. She travels to the city of Cusco, and she takes her products to sell in the Huancaro market. She has been in the business for 30 years, and it has gone very well for her thanks to the effort she puts into the business. Victoria needs the loan to buy seeds for things like flowers, cabbage, lettuce, and squash, etc. She is very grateful for the opportunity of the loan, and she promises to pay it on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy seeds for flowers, cabbage, lettuce, and squash, etc.

loans.name: Ghada

texts.en:
Ghada is a 39-year-old single woman living with her mother and sisters. For two years, she has owned a chocolate shop where she produces chocolates and she also makes designs and special stands for all occasions. 

Ghada has already taken her first loan from Kiva and she is pleased with her decision because in regard to her business progress, she reports that both her income and productivity have increased since taking the loan. She choose to repay her loan early and take a new loan of $1,200 to buy merchandise such as chocolate products and accessories to be ready to satisfy orders before the Easter holiday.

loans.use: Buy merchandise such as chocolates products and accessories

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel is 30 years old and married with one child. He has been selling general merchandise such as bread, maize flour, sugar, rice and cooking fat in his shop. He has been involved in this business for two years. He was previously employed as a casual laborer, but the need of having a stable income made him start his own business. Since he became a member of Faulu Kenya, he has expanded his business using the loans he obtained from the organization. He dreams of operating a wholesale shop in the future. He has requested a loan from Faulu Kenya to add a stock of maize flour, sugar, rice and cooking fat.

loans.use: To buy maize flour,sugar, rice and cooking fat

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en: Naseem, a resident of of the Pakistani city of Borewala, famous for its shrines, is the wife of I., who has operated a vegetable-selling business  for over 25 years. Purchasing his produce from the vegetable market, he sells it to various places from his cart. Naseem supports him by operating her  clothes-sewing business. They use both of their incomes to meet the financial expenses of their family. Naseen is now applying for a loan to buy seasonal vegetables in bulk so that her husband can expand his business.

loans.use: To buy seasonal vegetables to sell

loans.name: Akouèhoundé

texts.fr: Née en 1960, H. Akouèhoundé vit depuis 34 ans au quartier Gbèdjromédé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Akouèhoundé est mariée et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Akouèhoundé vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Akouèhoundé n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Depuis 16 ans, Akouèhoundé mène comme activité la vente d'acajou à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Cette activité lui génère des revenus l'aidant à assurer ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants. C'est toujours à Dantokpa que Akouèhoundé s'approvisionne. Akouèhoundé avait obtenu une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé, et a bien effectué le remboursement. En vue de renforcer son activité et d'augmenter son chiffre d'affaire, Akouèhoundé sollicite un deuxième prêt pour mieux faire face à la demande de la clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1960, Akouèhoundé H. has been living in the Gbèdjromédé district of Cotonou, Benin’s economic capital, for 34 years. Akouèhoundé is married and a mother of two children, who both attend school. She lives with her children and her husband. She never went to school. For 16 years, Akouèhoundé has been in the business of selling cashew nuts in Benin’s international market, Dantokpa. This business generates income, helping Akouèhoundé meet her own needs as well as those of her children. Akouèhoundé also buys her stock at Dantokpa. She has received one loan from ALIDé, which she successfully paid back. In order to strengthen her business and increase her sales, Akouèhoundé is asking for a second loan to better meet her clients’ demand.

Translated from French by Chelsea Rosendale, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cashew nuts

loans.name: David

texts.en: David is 30 years old and married with three children who go to school. He has been rearing chickens for sale for two years. He raises broilers and sells them to hotels when they are mature. He is married to a business lady and together they are able to pay their expenses and educate their children. David does not only raise livestock but is also a church pastor. He hopes to increase the number of his livestock and improve his living standards in the future. He has requested for a loan from Faulu Kenya to add to his stock of chickens.

loans.use: To buy more chickens

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Chantal

texts.en:
Chantal is 36 years old and is married with three children who are 4, 9 and 11 years old. Chantal is known in the business of selling new clothes, mainly children’s clothes. She has been in this business for about a year and the hours of her business are from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day except Saturday.

Chantal is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through adding a variety of styles such as men’s and women’s clothes.

With this loan, Chantal has a vision of growing her business to the extent that she can even start wholesaling. If she starts wholesaling, she hopes to earn more profits than before which, in turn, will be used for further reinvestment in her business and enable her to continue building a better future for her family.

loans.use: To add a variety of styles such as men's and women's clothes

loans.name: Gregorio

texts.es:
Gregorio, es natural de Yucay, tiene 34 años y pertenece al banco comunal “REYNA DE LOS ANGELES” de la Asociación Arariwa, tiene tres hijos, él es un padre responsable que busca a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos. 

Gregorio se dedica a la venta de calzados en el centro comercial “Sr. Torrechayoc” de Urubamba. Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su negocio, el socio requiere el préstamo  para comprar más zapatos, el anhelo del socio es tener una fábrica de zapatos. 

El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Gregorio is a native of Yucay. He is 34 years old and is a member of the “REYNA DE LOS ANGELES” (Queen of Angels) communal bank of the Arariwa Association. He has three sons and is a responsible father who is constantly looking for opportunities to get ahead and give his children a better future. Gregorio sells shoes in the “Sr. Torrechayoc” shopping center in Urubama. He is asking for this loan now that he has been doing this for several years and his business is doing well. He will use the money to buy more shoes. Someday he hopes to have his own show factory. He is grateful for the opportunity and promises to make his payments according to schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Shoes for resale

loans.name: Prosperidad Y Esperanza 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Luz is the coordinator of her group Prosperidad y Esperanza (Prosperity and Hope), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti). Her group is located in the urban areas surrounding Santiago where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure as a single mother with her two children.

Luz is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza and is excited to access capital at low interest rates. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling sweets by purchasing the necessary ingredients including sugar, coconut, milk and potatoes. She will use the profits to save towards her long term goal of opening a restaurant. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Coconut, sugar, milk and potatoes

loans.name: Pauline

texts.fr: Née en 1972 à Abomey-Calavi, T. Pauline est divorcée de son mari. Pauline a un enfant qui est scolarisé et qui vit avec elle. Il y a seulement deux mois que Pauline s'est installée avec son enfant au quartier Ayélawadjè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Pauline n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Pauline commercialise les produits de soins (pâtes dentifrices, brosses à dents, les médicaments génériques) de façon ambulante. Pauline s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et à Pharmaquick. Pauline exerce cette activité depuis sept ans et a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Pauline envisage développer et agrandir un peu plus son activité, afin de mieux faire face aux exigences des clients et de se faire plus de revenu. C'est ce qui l'amène à solliciter auprès de ALIDé, un troisième prêt.
texts.en:
Pauline T. was born in 1972 in Abomey-Calavi. She is divorced from her husband. She has one child who lives with her and attends school. Just two months ago, Pauline and her child moved to the Ayélawadjè district of Cotonou, Benin’s economic capital. Pauline did not go to school. To meet her needs, she works hawking personal care products (toothpaste, toothbrushes, generic medicine) from place to place. She buys her stock at Dantokpa, Benin’s international market, and at Pharmaquick. She has been doing this work for seven years, and has already benefitted from two loans with ALIDé, which she successfully paid back. Pauline is planning to develop and expand her business, in order to better meet her clients’ demands and increase her income. This is what brings her to request a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Chelsea Rosendale, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing toothpaste and toothbrushes

loans.name: Majidan's Group

texts.en: Majidan, married to M. Y., lives in the city of Borewala, Pakistan, famous for its shrines. A hardworking lady, Majidan operates a thread roll-making business, taking orders from the thread sellers and earning a monthly income of Pak Rs. 5,000, money that allows her to pay for the utilities. Her husband has been a vegetable seller for over 10 years, so Majidan is now requesting a loan to buy vegetables in bulk to expand her husband’s business.

loans.use: To buy seasonal vegetables for vegetable selling business

loans.name: Fanny Rosmery

texts.es:
Fanny tiene 35 años de edad, es madre soltera y vive junto a sus cuatro hijos de 13, 10, 8 y 6 años de edad en casa de su madre, ubicada en el distrito de Paiján, provincia de Ascope, en la región La Libertad, ubicada a 3 horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace 15 años se dedica a vender agua a diversos pobladores de las zonas alejadas del distrito que no cuentan con este servicio básico. El agua la extrae de un pozo hecho por sus abuelos en la casa donde reside. Ella la vende a un precio cómodo y las personas siempre recurren a ella, e incluso cuando se corta el suministro de agua en el distrito sus  vecinos acuden a su domicilio a solicitar el agua que necesitan.

Por otro lado también se gana la vida haciendo limpieza en algunas Instituciones de la zona, durante el dia divide su tiempo y visita a los locales e incluso casas que previamente han solicitado sus servicios. Estos dos ingresos son la única fuente de ingreso con la que su familia se sostiene.

Fanny ya ha trabajado con el fondo Kiva y esta muy agradecida con los prestamistas que la apoyaron. Gracias a su ayuda ha podido avanzar en la construcción de su vivienda, debido al inicio de clases escolares a nivel nacional, actualmente se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 700 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en la compra de utiles escolares y uniformes para sus menores hijos.
texts.en:
Fanny is 35 years old and a single mother who lives in her mother's home with her 4 children who are 13, 10, 8 and 6 years old. They live in the Paijan district in Ascope in the La Libertad province of Peru, about 3 hours from the city of Chiclayo. For the past 15 years, she has sold water to the people who live in areas far from her district where the population does not have this very basic service. She extracts the water from a well which was dug by her grandparents at her mother's home. She sells at a reasonable price and she has many repeat customers; also, when the water gets cut in her neighborhood, her neighbors come to her to get the water they need. She also makes money doing cleaning work in various institutions in the area; during the day she divides her time visiting the businesses and homes of her customers. These two forms of income are the only ways she can support her family. Fanny has worked with Kiva before and is very grateful to the lenders who supported her. Thanks to their help, she has been able to continue building her home. Currently she is requesting a $250 loan through Edpyme Alternative in order to buy school supplies and uniforms for her young children.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of uniforms and school supplies due to the beginning of classes

loans.name: Pauline

texts.fr: Née en 1967 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, D. Pauline est mariée à DEFLY Jules et est mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille vit au quartier Kpondéhou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Pauline n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et assurer les besoins de ses enfants, Pauline vend du charbon de bois à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Pauline achète ses produits. Pauline est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu trois crédits antérieurement, et qui ont été bien remboursés. Malgré la passion qu’elle a pour son activité, Pauline ne dispose pas suffisamment de moyens financiers pouvant lui permettre de la rehausser davantage et de faire face à la nombreuse demande de sa clientèle. C’est au vue de cela que Pauline sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Pauline D. was born in 1967 in Cotonou, Benin’s economic capital. She is married to Jules Defly, and is the mother of four children who all attend school. The family lives in the Kpondéhou district of Cotonou. Pauline and her husband cover the family’s expenses together. Pauline never went to school. To meet her own needs and those of her children, she sells charcoal out of her home. She buys her stock at Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. She is an old client of ALIDé, having previously received three loans, all of which were paid back. Although she is passionate about her business, Pauline doesn’t have the financial resources enabling her to build it up further and meet the high demand of her clients. With this in mind, she is asking for a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Chelsea Rosendale, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing bags of charcoal

loans.name: Naseem Akhtar's Group

texts.en: N. A. is an active citizen of a city named Borewala, famous for its shrines in Pakistan. Her husband, M. Altaf, has been an animal seller for the past 15 years, having acquired his knowledge from his father, who was in the same profession. He receives orders mainly from the butcher shops whose owners realize that to compromise on quality would mean a loss of customers. The shop owners deal with M. because they have full confidence in him. Therefore, N. is applying for a loan to expand her husband's animal-selling business.

loans.use: To buy animals to sell

loans.name: Tola

texts.en: Tola sells drinks to make a living. She hopes to grow her business. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more drinks to sell. She is 42 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The purchase and sale of sandals and plastic goods

loans.name: Dembagnouma Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Dembagnouma est composé de femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles nucléaires avec leurs enfants et époux dans le village de Sido, préfecture de Bougouni, troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de commerce. 
Dans l’intention d’améliorer leur capacité d’achat enfin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela pour faire le commerce de céréales. 
Elles sont à leur septième prêt de groupe,  et tous les six précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce nouveau  prêt elles comptent acheter, 700kg de fonio, 1tonne de petit mil et 500kg de maïs. Les produits sont achetés dans le marché de Sido et environnants pour être  revendus ensuite en détail ou au comptant aux grossistes de Bougouni. Leur clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes espèrent obtenir un bénéfice de 40.000FCFA par mois qui sera réutilisé dans leur activité.
texts.en:
The group Dembagnouma is composed of married women who average 32 years of age and four children each.  The women live in nuclear families with their children and husbands in the village of Sido, Prefecture of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through business. Intending to improve their purchasing capacity, in order to satisfy the needs of their customers, the women decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to do commerce in grains.  They are now on their seventh group loan.  The previous six loans were all properly repaid.  With this new loan, they intend to buy 700 kg of fonio (a local grain), a tonne of pearl millet, and 500 kg of corn.  The goods are purchased at the Sido market and from surrounding areas and are then sold, cash or credit accepted, to the wholesalers of Bougouni.  Their customer base is composed of men and women.  With this loan, the women hope to obtain a profit of 40,000 francs per month that will be reused in their work. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grains

loans.name: Miriya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Miriya sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 6 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux, dans le village de Sido, préfecture de Bougouni, troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de commerce. 
Dans l’intention d’acheter plus de produits, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela pour faire le commerce de boissons sucreries. 
Elles sont à leur sixième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt elles comptent acheter, 300 casiers de boisson sucrerie auprès de l’usine de production de boisson non alcoolisée  à Bamako. Toutes les boissons sont revendues en détail, au comptant ou à crédit dans le village de Sido à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt ces femmes espèrent obtenir un bénéfice mensuel de 35.000 FCFA dont une partie sera réutilisé dans leur activité et l’autre partie dans les frais d’éducation de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
All the women of the group Miriya are married and average 35 years of age and six children each.  And they live in traditional extended families with their brothers, sisters, co-wives, children, and husbands in the village of Sido, Prefecture of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women know one another through business.  Meaning to buy more goods, these women decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to do commerce in soft drinks.  They are now on their sixth group loan.  The previous loans were all properly repaid.   With this new loan, they intend to buy 300 cases of soft drinks from the production factory for non-alcoholic beverages in Bamako. All the drinks are sold retail, cash or credit accepted, in the village of Sido.  The customer base is composed of men and women.  With this loan, the women hope to obtain a monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA.  A portion of the profits will be reused in their work, and the other will go toward their children's education costs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying non-alcoholic beverages

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en: Irshad is a citizen of the city of Borewala, Pakistan, which is famous for its shrines. Her husband, L. A., has a medicine-selling business. To earn income, he obtains order from pharmacies. Irshad is applying for a loan to start their own medical shop. They will buy medicines for resale to earn a good profit.

loans.use: To start a medical store

loans.name: Unidas Para Triunfar 3 Group

texts.en:
Glenia is the coordinator of her group, Unidas Para Triunfar (United to Triumph), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti). Her group is located in Santiago, an urban area known for its tobacco industry where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and four children.

Glenia is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza and believes that Esperanza helps people most in need like her. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business, making bed coverings and sheets, by purchasing fabric. She will use the profits to invest in school supplies for her children and accruing savings. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Fabric for the production of bed covers and curtains

loans.name: Daha

texts.fr:
Monsieur Daha T. âgé de 28 ans est  enseignant de l’élémentaire dans une école située à quelques Kms de Thiès. Il enseigne la langue arabe  depuis 2 ans après sa formation à l’Ecole de  Formation des Instituteurs du Sénégal.   Pendant les grandes vacances, coïncidant toujours  avec la saison des pluies,  Monsieur T. cultive dans son champ situé au niveau de son village du mil, et de l’arachide.
 Cependant, Oustaz T. comme l’appellent ses élèves  a entamé depuis quelques temps des travaux de constructions  pour un bâtiment destiné à l’habitation.  Ainsi, il sollicite un prêt de 200 000 FCFA pour les finitions du   bâtiment.
texts.en:
Mr. Daha T., age 28, is a teacher at an elementary school located several kilometers from Thiès. He has been teaching Arabic for two years, since his training at the Senegalese Teachers' Training School. During the long vacation from school, which always coincides with the rainy season, Mr. T. cultivates millet and peanuts in his field located in his village. At the same time, Oustaz T., as his students call him, began construction work some time ago on a building intended for habitation. Thus, he is seeking a loan of 200,000 FCFA for finish work on the building.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finish construction work on his building

loans.name: Serieux Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sérieux est composé de femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles  traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux, dans le village de Sido, préfecture de Bougouni, troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de commerce.
Afin de satisfaire leurs clientèles de plus en plus nombreuses, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela pour faire le commerce de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles sont à leur sixième prêt de groupe, après avoir correctement remboursés les cinq prêts précédents. 
Avec ce prêt ces femmes comptent acheter, 35 boites de 2kg de concentrée de tomate, 25 sacs de 25kg de sel de cuisine, 60 paquets de 100 morceaux de cube maggi et diverses autres qualités de condiments. Les produits sont achetés auprès des grossistes de Bamako pour les être revendus ensuite dans le marché Sido à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes, en détail, au comptant et à crédit. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes espèrent obtenir un bénéfice mensuel de 35.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les frais d’habillements et santé de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
The group Sérieux (« serious ») is composed of married women with an average age of 28 and five children. They live in traditional families made larger by their brothers, sisters, co-spouses, children, and husbands, in the village of Sido, Bougouni prefecture, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. The women met through business relationships. In order to satisfy their growing number of clients, they decided to join the microfinace institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to sell condiments. They are on their sixth group loan, after having fully reimbursed the five previous loans. With this loan the women plan to buy 35 2-kilo cans of tomato paste, 25 25-kilo bags of culinary salt, 60 100-cube packages of “Maggi” boullion, and various other condiments. They get supplies from wholesalers in Bamako, then resell at the Sido market to a clientele composed essentially of woman, retail for cash and credit. With this loan the women hope to make a monthly profit of 35,000CFA which will be used for their children's clothing and health expenses.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of culinary condiments

loans.name: Jamila's Group

texts.en:
Jamila is a hardworking lady who has been offering her services as a seamstress in her community for the last four years. She runs her business in order to improve her family's standard of living. She sews designer and non-designer clothes very easily.
Jamila's husband is M. A., and they both want to give their children a good lifestyle. This purpose motivates them to overcome their problems. M. A. sells quilts and bedsheets to generate income. Once a month, he travels to various places to purchase these items for resale. Jamila is applying for a loan to expand her husband’s business by buying quilts and bedsheets in bulk.

loans.use: To buy quilts and bedsheets for resale

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 45 years old and married with three children. Her husband also works to support their home. Her children are excelling in their school and this gives her joy as a mother. She is a friendly and hardworking woman. She hopes to lift her business and family above poverty.

To make a living in Ibadan, Oyo State, Elizabeth sells vegetables at retail prices to her customers. She has a stall where she sells her vegetables. Her customers are usually friends and residents. She is requesting a loan of 150,000 nairas to purchase more vegetables to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: F. Elisabeth

texts.fr: Née en 1976, K. F. Elisabeth est mariée à AHOUANADE Dieudonné un mécanicien. Le couple a trois enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Il y a près de 13 ans que la famille s'est installée à Agbalilamè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Le couple se partage ensemble les différentes charges de la maison. Elisabeth n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et contribuer aux charges familiales, Elisabeth vend diverses sortes de bidons. Parallèlement à cette activité, Elisabeth vend des tissus de façon ambulante. Elisabeth s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Elisabeth mène cette activité depuis 16 ans environs et a obtenu une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Elisabeth avait bien remboursé le premier prêt. Afin d'augmenter le stock de ses produits et d'accroître sa clientèle, Elisabeth sollicite un second prêt.
texts.en:
Born in 1976, F. Elisabeth K. is married to Dieudonné AHOUANADE, a mechanic. The couple has three children, of whom some are attending school. Some 13 years ago the family settled in Agbalilamè, in the Sèmè-Podji commune. The couple jointly shares family expenses. Elizabeth has only attended primary school. To meet her needs and contribute to the handling of family expenses, she sells various types of containers. As a secondary activity, she also sells pieces of fabric as an itinerant vendor. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. Elizabeth has been in this line of business for about 16 years and has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was repaid in full. She is now requesting a second loan, to increase her stock supply and expand her customer base.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy containers and fabric

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet is a 42-year-old single mother of two children. She is the breadwinner for her family and looks after the four people she lives with. Currently, she resides in a rented house in Hoima town, Uganda where she operates a bar.

Annet has been in her business for ten years and, over the years, it has grown with the help of the loan facilities from HOFOKAM and contributions from her farming and she has been able to construct a house in her village. Even then she says she hopes to set up a grocery as she grows older which, she says, would suit her advancing age.

The purpose of the loan is to buy alcohol and soft drinks to sell in her bar.

loans.use: To buy more alcohol and soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Haleema's Group

texts.en:
Haleema is a wife of A. M. and they both live in the city of Borewala, Pakistan. Borewala is famous for its shrines.
Her husband runs a dairy business from their home. Haleema helps him with milking the cow. They both get up early to milk the cow, then after A. M. has gone into the community to sell the milk Haleema stays home to do the domestic chores and take care of the family. Haleema is requesting a loan to buy another dairy cow to expand their milk-selling business.

loans.use: To buy another dairy cow for their milk-selling business

loans.name: Wassim

texts.en: Three years ago Wassim, a 22-year-old single man living with his parents and three siblings, established a computer business to help provide various types of reports for members of his community. With his current loan request of US $1,200, Wassim will be able to purchase a photocopier and better market his services and increase the liquidity of his business. Wassim told the Ameen loan officer that the loan amount will be sufficient to fulfill his business objectives for the coming months. He also says that he hopes his business productivity and income will increase as a result of the loan.

loans.use: To purchase a photocopy machine

loans.name: Julia Lucila

texts.es:
Julia tiene 43 años de edad, se separó de su esposo hace 8 años y vive junto a su hija de 18 años de edad en el distrito de José Leonardo Ortiz, ubicado a 5 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace 10 años tiene un negocio de venta de ropa en una zona aledaña al Mercado Modelo (el principal mercado de la ciudad de Chiclayo) llamada Galerías Rosadas, ella vende ropa tanto nueva como usada y trabaja desde muy temprano en la mañana hasta muy avanzada la tarde.

Su negocio es la única fuente de ingreso que sostiene a su familia, por lo que ella trata de dar todo de sí para sacar su negocio adelante, gracias a esta actividad ella ha podido apoyar a su hija en sus estudios de enfermería, lo que la llena de orgullo.

Actualmente Julia desea implementar el negocio con nuevas prendas, sobretodo de la temporada otoño – invierno, ya que el verano terminará en las proximas semanas y ella desea tener la mercadería suficiente para responder a la demanda una vez cambiada la estación. Por ello se encuentra solicitando por a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos soles.

Su mas grande anhelo es seguir ampliando su negocio y convertirse en una comerciante mayorista. Ella ya ha trabajado anteriormente con el fondo Kiva y se encuentra muy agradecida con la ayuda brindada, este es su segundo préstamo y ha demostrado responsabilidad y puntualidad en sus pagos.
texts.en:
Julia is 43 years old and separated from her husband 8 years ago; she lives with her 18 year old daughter in the Jose Leonardo Ortiz district about 5 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. For the past 10 years, she has sold clothing in the region around the Mercado Modelo (the principal market in Chiclayo) called Galerias Rosadas. She sells new and used clothing and works from early in the morning to late in the evening. Her business is her only form of income to support her family which is why she gives her all to grow her business. Thanks to her business, she has been able to help her daughter in her nursing education; this makes her very proud. Currently Julia would like to supply the store with new clothing, more than anything fall and winter clothes since summer is coming to an end in the next few weeks. She would like to have enough inventory to fulfill the demand when the seasons change. This is why she is seeking a loan from Edpyme Alternativa for $175. Her dream is to continue growing her business and to become a wholesale merchant. She has worked with Kiva before and is very grateful for the support she has received; this is her 2nd loan and she has been punctual with her payments in the past.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothing to grow the business during the fall and winter

loans.name: Gildardo De Jesus

texts.es:
Gildardo de Jesús C. P. vive en el municipio de Baranoa, municipio ubicado en la carretera que conduce desde Barranquilla a Cartagena. Con 58 años, está casado y tiene cuatro hijos en las edades de 30 y 24 años. Se dedica a la talabartería y marroquinería en ese municipio, donde fabrica y vende, entre otros, billeteras, sillas para caballo y aperos. Este es su segundo crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, el anterior le permitió comprar en mayor volumen de materias primas e insumos que incrementaron su producción y su mercado.  Ahora solicita un crédito por valor de $1.500.000, con el fin de invertirlo otra vez en la compra de materias primas e insumos, como cueros y en herrajes.
El señor Gildardo era tecnólogo veterinario e inició sus trabajos en fincas donde además de prestar servicios para los animales, comenzó a reparar aperos de cabeza y sillas de caballo, hasta que posteriormente se especializó en talabartería y marroquinería en cursos que realizó con el SENA. Ahora elabora billeteras, sillas para caballo y aperos, creando su mercado en el sector agropecuario de Baranoa, Sabanalarga y Barranquilla después del 2003 cuando se mudó a Baranoa, zona gastronómica que se destaca por su Festival de Chicharrón. A pesar de sus éxitos considera que uno de sus principales es la falta de capital para incrementar la producción; por eso sueña con adquirir una máquina de coser que le permitiría dar un mayor acabado al producto, ya que actualmente este proceso se realiza a mano.
texts.en:
Gildardo de Jesus C. P. lives in the town of Baranoa, located on the highway that goes from Barranquilla to Cartagena. He is 58 years old and married with 4 children, from 24-30 years old. He works makes saddles and leather goods in the town; he makes and sells wallets, saddles and farm tools. This is his second loan through Mario Santo Domingo Foundation; his previous loan helped him to buy his materials in greater quantities to increase his production and his sales. Now he is seeking a $800 loan to invest in his business and buy more materials like leather and iron fittings. Gildardo was a veterinarian and he began his work on farms where, in addition to helping the animals, he began to repair the farm tools and saddles; finally, he decided to specialize in saddles and leather work through classes he took at SENA. Now he makes wallets, saddles and farm tools, creating his goods in the agricultural sector of Baranoa, Sabanalarga, and Barranquilla; in 2003, he moved to Baranoa, a region famous for its food and its Chicharron Festival. In spite of his success, he feels like one thing he lacks is working capital to increase his production; he dreams of buying a sewing machine that will help him better finish his products since he currently does it by hand.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials like leather and iron fittings

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah is a 37-year-old married woman with one child. She and her husband both contribute to the welfare of their family.

Norah has a clothing business and also sells dry foods in Hoima town, Uganda. She decided to indulge in two lines of business because she says the clothing business is sometimes seasonal so, when it is not at its peak, she is busy with selling cereals and dry foods.

Norah would like to be a large scale supplier of produce with big stores. The purpose of the loan is to buy rice to sell.

loans.use: To buy more rice to sell

loans.name: Alice

texts.fr: Née en 1970 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, H. Alice vit depuis 30 ans à Sèkandji dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Alice est mariée à DJIBOM Gérome et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Alice vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure les différentes charges de la maison. Il y a environs 10 ans que Alice vend, par le système de distribution, des produits de soins (pâtes dentifrices, brosses à dents, cure-dent, des médicaments génériques, etc.). Alice s'approvisionne à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Alice a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé et l'a bien remboursé. Dans le souci d'auqmenter son capital et de renforcer son activité, Alice souhaite obtenir un deuxième concours financier auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1970 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Alice H. has lived for 30 years in Sèkandji in the Sèmè-Podji commune. She is married to Gérome DJIBOM and is the mother of three children, all having attended (or still attending) school. Alice lives with her children and her husband, with whom she jointly shares the household expenses. For the past ten years, Alice has been selling personal care products through the distribution system (toothpaste, toothbrushes, toothpicks, generic pharmaceutical drugs, etc.). She gets her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Alice has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which has been repaid in full. She is now requesting a second financial loan from ALIDé, to increase her working capital and strengthen her activity.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy toothpaste, toothbrushes, toothpicks, generic pharmaceutical drugs

loans.name: Moreen

texts.en: Moreen is a 25-year-old woman and a single mother of one child who is four years old. She looks after a family of four people and they live in a rented house. She operates a bar business in Hoima, Uganda and has been in the business for four years. She says she encounters challenges of bad debtors but still says the business has been able to sustain her and her family. She dreams of having a bar on the main street of the town where there are many clients. She intends to buy alcohol and drinks for selling in the bar and paying school fees for her child.

loans.use: To buy alcohol and drinks to sell and to pay school fees for her child.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy turkeys and guiney fowls to raise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy and sell prepared rice

loans.name: Perlas Group

texts.es: El grupo D. Mujeres Perlas  Acuden a la Asociaciòn ASDIR para poder ayudarles en el incremento D. capital ya que ellas venden ropa tipica   en otros municipios y lugares para poder salir avante ya que con este trabajo  han logrado salir en la vida, ya que tiene 8 años atras  D. realizar dicha ventas y por ello piden esta ayuda y asi surtir la mercaderia y tener buenas ganancias y tener otro nivel D. vida.
texts.en:
The Perlas (Pearls) group of women have come to the ASDIR association to request assistance to raise capital. They sell traditional clothing in other municipalities and places in order to get ahead. With this work they have been able to get ahead in life. They have been selling clothes for 8 years. They are requesting this loan to add inventory, have strong earnings, and have a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raise capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Femmmes Commerçantes N°1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty N. l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba S., pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Parmi les sous groupes nous avons le sous groupe Femmes Commerçantes N°1. C’est le sous groupe donné à la charge de la présidente Madame Maty N., une femme très dynamique et âgée de 55 ans.  Mère de 8 enfants, cette dame commerce depuis plus de 20 ans des tissus et divers types de  légumes. Elle est dans ce sous  groupe avec Madame Coumba S. qui vend de l’arachide, savon  et du sucre, Madame Fatou D. vendeuse de niébé (haricots locaux) et légumes au marché, Madame Aminata N., une commerçante ambulante de téléphones portables et de Madame Khady M. qui a un petit restaurant à Touba une ville située à 170 Kms de Thiès.
texts.en:
The “Femmes Commerçantes” Group (F.C.), as its name indicates, is a network of women who are active in the commercial sector. It is based in Grand Thiès and was founded in 1992 by Ms. Maty N., the network’s current president. She developed the idea following a training session she followed, organised by the OXFAM NGO in Thiès. She is therefore quite knowledgeable about group management, entrepreneurship, etc. The network members are extremely devoted and meet once a month. There are admission charges to become a group member, and afterwards each member must contribute 200 FCFA monthly towards a common solidarity fund. As they wanted additional financing, they decided to join U-IMCEC. This is why their network was split into 19 sub-groups of five persons each, to ensure better profit from the financing. For the second time they are requesting a loan of 100,000 FCFA per member, that is 500,000 FCFA per sub-group, to develop their various activities. Reimbursements are made at the monthly meetings to the group president assisted by the group treasurer, Ms. Coumba S., who then reimburse U-IMCEC. In the words of its president, the network has only one objective: to fight against poverty in households. The network currently numbers 19 sub-groups, each with its own president and treasurer. Among the sub-groups there is the “Femmes Commerçantes n°1” sub-group, headed by the president Ms. Maty N., a very dynamic 55-year-old woman. Mother of eight children, this lady has retailed fabrics and various types of vegetables for the past twenty years. She is joined in this sub-group by Ms. Coumba S., who sells peanuts, soap and sugar; Ms. Fatou D. who sells niébé (a local bean) and vegetables at the market; Ms. Aminata N., an itinerant vendor of mobile phones; and Ms. Khady M. who runs a small restaurant in Touba, a town located 170 kilometers from Thiès.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Resupply merchandise

loans.name: Hector Wilmer

texts.es:
Hector es un padre de familia que tiene 34 años de edad, vive junto a su esposa y a sus dos hijos menores de edad en una casa brindada por su padre para habitarla, la cual queda ubicada en un  pueblo joven del distrito de Pimentel, ubicado a veinte minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo, las condiciones de vida del cliente son precarias, su casa es de quincha con barro dividido por dentro con esteras, el piso es de tierra. 

Se dedica a la venta de pescado desde hace 10 años aproximadamente, compra su mercadería en el  terminal pesquero del vecino distrito de Santa Rosa y la vende de manera ambulatoria en Pimentel y en Chiclayo. Esta actividad es la única fuente de ingresos con la que solventa los gastos familiares, por ello siempre da lo mejor de si para mantener su negocio. 

Actualmente su negocio esta captando mas numero de clientes lo cual hace que sus ventas sean mayores, por lo que Hector desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más mercadería, por ello se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles.

Hector es un padre trabajador y que siempre trata de sacar a su familia de la condicion en la que viven, su mayor anhelo es poder construir su vivienda de material noble para ofrecerles un techo seguro. El ya ha trabajado anteriormente con Nuestra Institucion y ha demostrado responsabilidad al momento de asumir sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Hector is a hard working father. He is 34 years old and lives with his wife and two young children in a home provided by his father. The home is located in the Pimentel district, located 20 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. His living conditions are precarious. His home is a “quincha” home (a traditional construction system that uses a wood and cane framework, covered in mud and plaster) with a dirt floor. He has been selling fish for the past ten years. He buys his merchandise at the fishing terminal in the neighboring district of Santa Rosa and he sells it on foot in Pimentel and Chiclayo. This is the only source of income that pays for his family’s needs and he gives all he can to keep the business running. Lately his business has been bringing in more customers which has resulted in increased sales. He would like to expand his business by buying more merchandise, so Hector is requesting this loan for 1,000 PEN ($350) through Edpyme Alternativa. Hector is a hard working father who always tries to move his family ahead and tries to bring them up from the condition in which they live. His greatest desire is to build a sturdy house in order to offer them a solid roof over their heads. He has worked with our institution in the past and has demonstrated his responsibility in making his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fish for resale

loans.name: Victor Moises

texts.es:
Víctor, es soltero tiene 2 hijas una de las cuales se encuentra en edad escolar y la 
otra se encuentra preparándose en una academia preuniversitaria, el cliente posee una 
carpintería la cual la inicio hace algunos años atrás, teniendo experiencia y un buen 
numero de clientes , el realiza buenos trabajos con buenos acabados y de buena 
calidad, sus clientes retornan siempre por sus servicios, el sueño de Víctor es que 
sus dos hijas puedan tener una buena educación y así puedan enfrentar el futuro, por   
este motivo es que el destina todos los ingresos para este fin. Solicita el crédito 
para la compra de mercadería y así poder incrementar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Victor is single and has two daughters, one who is school-aged, and the other is in academy preparing for college. He has a carpentry business that he started a few years ago. He is experienced and has a good number of customers. He does good work with nice finishing and high quality. His customers always return for his services. Victor's dream is that his two daughters receive a good education and be prepared for the future. For this reason, all of his income goes towards this goal. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of merchandise, so that he can increase his earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de Mercaderia

loans.name: Marcelino José

texts.es:
Marcelino S. P., tiene 55 años de edad y vive  en el barrio Ciudad Modesto al sur occidente de Barranquilla, con su cónyuge y sus hijos que tienen entre los 21 y 30 años de edad. Proveniente del departamento de  Sucre, llegó a vivir en Bosconia en el Departamento del Cesar y con pocas posibilidades de emplearse en ese lugar, llegó a Barranquilla y montó un negocio inicial de venta de juguetes, que lo sostenía, pero solo le generaba prosperidad en épocas de Diciembre; fue así como decidió desde hace 10 años ubicarse en diversos sectores del centro, para vender en una pequeña carretilla víveres, como aceite, harina, azúcar, arroz y otros artículos de la canasta familiar , alguno de los cuales compra por pacas y él reempaca y vende en porciones de libra o de onzas en una zona muy comercial ubicada en el Centro de Barranquilla. En la actualidad, solicita un financiamiento por valor de $1.300.000 para comprar jabón, azúcar, arroz, aceite y medicinas que no requieren prescripción médica, que usualmente mantienen las familias en los botiquines personales.
Marcelino expresa que desde hace 16 años ha sobrevivido a partir de este negocio y que cuando llegó a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo hace 10 años, ingresó en un grupo solidario de 4 personas, en la actualidad tiene mas de 10 créditos recibidos de manera individual, que le han ayudado a aumentar sus utilidades y ha podido pasar de vender en una vieja carretilla por las calles,  a un gran cubo de madera con puerta metálica que tiene seguridad y puede estacionarlo. Desde su ingreso a la Fundación, ha mejorado su vivienda y ha sostenido a su familia; su sueño es ampliarlo invirtiéndole mercancía, comprándola de contado y ese es precisamente su gran desafío, salir de compromisos adquiridos con proveedores que le acreditan a un alto precio.
texts.en:
Marcelino S. P. is 55 years old. He lives in the Ciudad Modesto neighborhood in the southwestern part of Barranquilla. He lives with his wife and their children who are between 21 and 30 years old. Originally from the state of Sucre, he moved to Bosconia in the state of Cesar, but with few possibilities for work, he then moved to Barranquilla and opened a business initially selling toys, which he used to support himself, but he made good money during December. So 10 years ago he decided to locate himself in various area of the city center, and sell basic goods such as oil, flour, sugar, rice and other items from a small cart. Some items he purchases in bulk and repackages them to sell in portions of one pound or ounces. He works in a very busy commercial zone in the center of Barranquilla. He is requesting a loan for $1.300.000 to purchase soap, sugar, rice, oil, and non-prescription medicines, which families usually have in their medicine cabinets. Marcelino has been living off this business for 16 years. When the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation arrived 10 years ago, he joined a group of 4 people. He has taken out more than 10 loans as an individual, which have helped him to increase his earnings and to be able to move from selling from an old cart in the streets to a large wooden box with a metal door that locks and that he can park. Since he has joined the Foundation, he has improved his home and been able to support his family. His dream is to grow his business by adding merchandise, paying for it with cash. This is precisely his great challenge, to pay off the obligations he has to suppliers who have provided him credit at a high price.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase goods like soap, sugar, rice, oil and medicine in larger quantities.

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°2 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba Seck, pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Pour le sous groupe Femmes Commerçantes N°2,  Madame Yacine F. qui était le seul à parler le français est nommée la présidente. Elle est  mariée et âgée de 22 ans. Elle commerce de l’huile, de la pâte d’arachide et  du jus local. Ainsi, les quatre autres membres sont : Madame Awa N. vendeuse de légumes, Madame Coura N. qui vend des poissons frais au marché Grand Thiès, Madame Fatou Sakho N.  vendeuse de légumes au marché et Madame Isseu T., qui au marché Okass vend du petit déjeuner et des légumes.
texts.en:
The “Femmes Commerçantes” Group (F.C.), as its name indicates, is a network of women who are active in the commercial sector. It is based in Grand Thiès and was founded in 1992 by Ms. Maty Niakh, the network’s current president. She developed the idea following a training session she followed, organised by the OXFAM NGO in Thiès. She is therefore quite knowledgeable about group management, entrepreneurship, etc. The network members are extremely devoted and meet once a month. There are admission charges to become a group member, and afterwards each member must contribute 200 FCFA monthly towards a common solidarity fund. As they wanted additional financing, they decided to join U-IMCEC. This is why their network was split into 19 sub-groups of five persons each, to ensure better profit from the financing. For the second time they are requesting a loan of 100,000 FCFA per member, that is 500,000 FCFA per sub-group, to develop their various activities. Reimbursements are made at the monthly meetings to the group president assisted by the group treasurer, Ms. Coumba Seck, who in turn reimburse U-IMCEC. In the words of its president, the network has only one objective: to fight against poverty in households. The network currently counts 19 sub-groups, each with its own president and treasurer. For sub-group “Femmes Commerçantes n°2”, Ms. Yacine F. was elected president, being the only member who spoke French. She is married and 22 years old. She sells vegetable oil, peanut butter and local fruit juice.
